title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Direct Discrimination
content: (1)A person (A) discriminates against another (B) if, because of a protected characteristic, A treats B less favourably than A treats or would treat others.  (2)If the protected characteristic is age, A does not discriminate against B if A can show A's treatment of B to be a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim.  (3)If the protected characteristic is disability, and B is not a disabled person, A does not discriminate against B only because A treats or would treat disabled persons more favourably than A treats B.  (4)If the protected characteristic is marriage and civil partnership, this section applies to a contravention of Part 5 (work) only if the treatment is because it is B who is married or a civil partner.  (5)If the protected characteristic is race, less favourable treatment includes segregating B from others.  (6)If the protected characteristic is sexâ  (a)less favourable treatment of a woman includes less favourable treatment of her because she is breast-feeding;  (b)in a case where B is a man, no account is to be taken of special treatment afforded to a woman in connection with pregnancy [F1, childbirth or maternity].

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Discrimination Arising from Disability
content: A person (A) discriminates against a disabled person (B) ifâ  (a)A treats B unfavourably because of something arising in consequence of B's disability, and  (b)A cannot show that the treatment is a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim.  Subsection (1) does not apply if A shows that A did not know, and could not reasonably have been expected to know, that B had the disability.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Duty to Make Adjustments
content: Where this Act imposes a duty to make reasonable adjustments on a person, this section, sections 21 and 22 and the applicable Schedule apply; and for those purposes, a person on whom the duty is imposed is referred to as A.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Duty to Make Adjustments
content: The duty comprises the following three requirements.  (1)The first requirement is a requirement, where a provision, criterion or practice of A's puts a disabled person at a substantial disadvantage in relation to a relevant matter in comparison with persons who are not disabled, to take such steps as it is reasonable to have to take to avoid the disadvantage.  (2)The second requirement is a requirement, where a physical feature puts a disabled person at a substantial disadvantage in relation to a relevant matter in comparison with persons who are not disabled, to take such steps as it is reasonable to have to take to avoid the disadvantage.  (3)The third requirement is a requirement, where a disabled person would, but for the provision of an auxiliary aid, be put at a substantial disadvantage in relation to a relevant matter in comparison with persons who are not disabled, to take such steps as it is reasonable to have to take to provide the auxiliary aid.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Duty to Make Adjustments
content: Where the first or third requirement relates to the provision of information, the steps which it is reasonable for A to have to take include steps for ensuring that in the circumstances concerned the information is provided in an accessible format.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Duty to Make Adjustments
content: A person (A) who is subject to a duty to make reasonable adjustments is not (subject to express provision to the contrary) entitled to require a disabled person, in relation to whom A is required to comply with the duty, to pay to any extent A's costs of complying with the duty.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Duty to Make Adjustments
content: In relation to the second requirement, a reference in this section or an applicable Schedule to avoiding a substantial disadvantage includes a reference toâ  (a)removing the physical feature in question,  (b)altering it, or  (c)providing a reasonable means of avoiding it.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Duty to Make Adjustments
content: A reference in this section, section 21 or 22 or an applicable Schedule (apart from paragraphs 2 to 4 of Schedule 4) to a physical feature is a reference toâ  (a)a feature arising from the design or construction of a building,  (b)a feature of an approach to, exit from or access to a building,  (c)a fixture or fitting, or furniture, furnishings, materials, equipment or other chattels, in or on premises, or  (d)any other physical element or quality.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Failure To Comply With Duty
content: A failure to comply with the first, second or third requirement is a failure to comply with a duty to make reasonable adjustments.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Failure To Comply With Duty
content: A discriminates against a disabled person if A fails to comply with that duty in relation to that person.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Failure To Comply With Duty
content: A provision of an applicable Schedule which imposes a duty to comply with the first, second or third requirement applies only for the purpose of establishing whether A has contravened this Act by virtue of subsection (2); a failure to comply is, accordingly, not actionable by virtue of another provision of this Act or otherwise.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Regulations
content: Regulations may prescribeâ  (a) matters to be taken into account in deciding whether it is reasonable for A to take a step for the purposes of a prescribed provision of an applicable Schedule;  (b) descriptions of persons to whom the first, second or third requirement does not apply.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Regulations
content: Regulations may make provision as toâ  (a)circumstances in which it is, or in which it is not, reasonable for a person of a prescribed description to have to take steps of a prescribed description;  (b)what is, or what is not, a provision, criterion or practice;  (c)things which are, or which are not, to be treated as physical features;  (d)things which are, or which are not, to be treated as alterations of physical features;  (e)things which are, or which are not, to be treated as auxiliary aids.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Harassment
content: A person (A) harasses another (B) ifâ  (a) A engages in unwanted conduct related to a relevant protected characteristic, and  (b) the conduct has the purpose or effect ofâ  (i) violating B's dignity, or  (ii) creating an intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive environment for B.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Harassment
content: A also harasses B ifâ  (a)A engages in unwanted conduct of a sexual nature, and  (b)the conduct has the purpose or effect referred to in subsection (1)(b).

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Harassment
content: A also harasses B ifâ  (a)A or another person engages in unwanted conduct of a sexual nature or that is related to gender reassignment or sex,  (b)the conduct has the purpose or effect referred to in subsection (1)(b), and  (c)because of B's rejection of or submission to the conduct, A treats B less favourably than A would treat B if B had not rejected or submitted to the conduct.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Harassment
content: In deciding whether conduct has the effect referred to in subsection (1)(b), each of the following must be taken into accountâ  (a)the perception of B;  (b)the other circumstances of the case;  (c)whether it is reasonable for the conduct to have that effect.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Harassment
content: The relevant protected characteristics areâ  age; disability; gender reassignment; race; religion or belief; sex; sexual orientation.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Victimisation
content: A person (A) victimises another person (B) if A subjects B to a detriment becauseâ  (a)B does a protected act, or  (b)A believes that B has done, or may do, a protected act.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Victimisation
content: Each of the following is a protected actâ  (a)bringing proceedings under this Act;  (b)giving evidence or information in connection with proceedings under this Act;  (c)doing any other thing for the purposes of or in connection with this Act;  (d)making an allegation (whether or not express) that A or another person has contravened this Act.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Victimisation
content: Giving false evidence or information, or making a false allegation, is not a protected act if the evidence or information is given, or the allegation is made, in bad faith.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Victimisation
content: This section applies only where the person subjected to a detriment is an individual.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Victimisation
content: The reference to contravening this Act includes a reference to committing a breach of an equality clause or rule.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Disposals, etc.
content: A person (A) who has the right to dispose of premises must not discriminate against another (B)â  (a)as to the terms on which A offers to dispose of the premises to B;  (b)by not disposing of the premises to B;  (c)in A's treatment of B with respect to things done in relation to persons seeking premises.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Disposals, etc.
content: Where an interest in a commonhold unit cannot be disposed of unless a particular person is a party to the disposal, that person must not discriminate against a person by not being a party to the disposal.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Disposals, etc.
content: A person who has the right to dispose of premises must not, in connection with anything done in relation to their occupation or disposal, harassâ  (a)a person who occupies them;  (b)a person who applies for them.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Disposals, etc.
content: A person (A) who has the right to dispose of premises must not victimise another (B)â  (a)as to the terms on which A offers to dispose of the premises to B;  (b)by not disposing of the premises to B;  (c)in A's treatment of B with respect to things done in relation to persons seeking premises.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Disposals, etc.
content: Where an interest in a commonhold unit cannot be disposed of unless a particular person is a party to the disposal, that person must not victimise a person by not being a party to the disposal.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Disposals, etc.
content: In the application of section 26 for the purposes of subsection (3), neither of the following is a relevant protected characteristicâ  (a)religion or belief;  (b)sexual orientation.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Permission for Disposal
content: If a person or body (such as a housing association) must give permission for someone to sublet, transfer or dispose of a home, they must not discriminate or retaliate against the person requesting that permission.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Management
content: A person (A) who manages premises must not discriminate against a person (B) who occupies the premisesâ  (a)in the way in which A allows B, or by not allowing B, to make use of a benefit or facility;  (b)by evicting B (or taking steps for the purpose of securing B's eviction);  (c)by subjecting B to any other detriment.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Management
content: A person who manages premises must not, in relation to their management, harassâ  (a)a person who occupies them;  (b)a person who applies for them.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Management
content: A person (A) who manages premises must not victimise a person (B) who occupies the premisesâ  (a)in the way in which A allows B, or by not allowing B, to make use of a benefit or facility;  (b)by evicting B (or taking steps for the purpose of securing B's eviction);  (c)by subjecting B to any other detriment.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Leasehold and commonhold premises and common parts
content: A duty to make reasonable adjustments applies toâ  (a)a controller of let premises;  (b)a controller of premises to let;  (c)a commonhold association;  (d)a responsible person in relation to common parts.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Leasehold and commonhold premises and common parts
content: A controller of let premises isâ  (a)a person by whom premises are let, or  (b)a person who manages them.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Leasehold and commonhold premises and common parts
content: A controller of premises to let isâ  (a)a person who has premises to let, or  (b)a person who manages them.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Leasehold and commonhold premises and common parts
content: The reference in subsection (1)(c) to a commonhold association is a reference to the association in its capacity as the person who manages a commonhold unit.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Leasehold and commonhold premises and common parts
content: A responsible person in relation to common parts isâ  (a)where the premises to which the common parts relate are let (and are not part of commonhold land or in Scotland), a person by whom the premises are let;  (b)where the premises to which the common parts relate are part of commonhold land, the commonhold association.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Leasehold and commonhold premises and common parts
content: (6)Common parts areâ  (a)in relation to let premises (which are not part of commonhold land or in Scotland), the structure and exterior of, and any common facilities within or used in connection with, the building or part of a building which includes the premises;  (b)in relation to commonhold land, every part of the commonhold which is not for the time being a commonhold unit in accordance with the commonhold community statement.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Leasehold and commonhold premises and common parts
content: A reference to letting includes a reference to sub-letting; and for the purposes of subsection (1)(a) and (b), a reference to let premises includes premises subject to a right to occupy.

title: Equality Act 2010
heading: Leasehold and commonhold premises and common parts
content: This section does not apply to premises of such description as may be prescribed.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to grant injunctions
content: A court may grant an injunction under this section against a person aged 10 or over (âthe respondentâ) if two conditions are met.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to grant injunctions
content: The first condition is that the court is satisfied, on the balance of probabilities, that the respondent has engaged or threatens to engage in anti-social behaviour.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to grant injunctions
content: The second condition is that the court considers it just and convenient to grant the injunction for the purpose of preventing the respondent from engaging in anti-social behaviour.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to grant injunctions
content: An injunction under this section may for the purpose of preventing the respondent from engaging in anti-social behaviourâ  (a)prohibit the respondent from doing anything described in the injunction;  (b)require the respondent to do anything described in the injunction.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to grant injunctions
content: Prohibitions and requirements in an injunction under this section must, so far as practicable, be such as to avoidâ  (a)any interference with the times, if any, at which the respondent normally works or attends school or any other educational establishment;  (b)any conflict with the requirements of any other court order or injunction to which the respondent may be subject.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to grant injunctions
content: An injunction under this section mustâ  (a)specify the period for which it has effect, or  (b)state that it has effect until further order.  In the case of an injunction granted before the respondent has reached the age of 18, a period must be specified and it must be no more than 12 months.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to grant injunctions
content: An application for an injunction under this section must be made toâ  (a)a youth court, in the case of a respondent aged under 18;  (b)the High Court or the county court, in any other case.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Meaning of anti-social behaviour
content: (1)In this Part âanti-social behaviourâ meansâ  (a)conduct that has caused, or is likely to cause, harassment, alarm or distress to any person,  (b)conduct capable of causing nuisance or annoyance to a person in relation to that person's occupation of residential premises, or  (c)conduct capable of causing housing-related nuisance or annoyance to any person.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Meaning of anti-social behaviour
content: Subsection (1)(b) applies only where the injunction under section 1 is applied for byâ  (a)a housing provider,  (b)a local authority, or  (c)a chief officer of police.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Meaning of anti-social behaviour
content: In subsection (1)(c) âhousing-relatedâ means directly or indirectly relating to the housing management functions ofâ  (a)a housing provider, or  (b)a local authority.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Meaning of anti-social behaviour
content: For the purposes of subsection (3) the housing management functions of a housing provider or a local authority includeâ  (a)functions conferred by or under an enactment;  (b)the powers and duties of the housing provider or local authority as the holder of an estate or interest in housing accommodation.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Requirements included in injunctions
content: An injunction that includes a requirement must specify the person who is to be responsible for supervising compliance with the requirement.  The person may be an individual or an organisation.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Requirements included in injunctions
content: Before including a requirement, the court must receive evidence about its suitability and enforceability fromâ  (a)the individual to be specified under subsection (1), if an individual is to be specified;  (b)an individual representing the organisation to be specified under subsection (1), if an organisation is to be specified.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Requirements included in injunctions
content: Before including two or more requirements, the court must consider their compatibility with each other.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Requirements included in injunctions
content: It is the duty of a person specified under subsection (1)â  (a)to make any necessary arrangements in connection with the requirements for which the person has responsibility (the ârelevant requirementsâ);  (b)to promote the respondent's compliance with the relevant requirements;  (c)if the person considers that the respondentâ  (i)has complied with all the relevant requirements, or  (ii)has failed to comply with a relevant requirement,  to inform the person who applied for the injunction and the appropriate chief officer of police.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Requirements included in injunctions
content: A respondent subject to a requirement included in an injunction under section 1 mustâ  (a)keep in touch with the person specified under subsection (1) in relation to that requirement, in accordance with any instructions given by that person from time to time;  (b)notify the person of any change of address.  These obligations have effect as requirements of the injunction.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power of Arrest
content: A court granting an injunction under section 1 may attach a power of arrest to a prohibition or requirement of the injunction if the court thinks thatâ  (a)the anti-social behaviour in which the respondent has engaged or threatens to engage consists of or includes the use or threatened use of violence against other persons, or  (b)there is a significant risk of harm to other persons from the respondent.  âRequirementâ here does not include one that has the effect of requiring the respondent to participate in particular activities.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power of Arrest
content: If the court attaches a power of arrest, the injunction may specify a period for which the power is to have effect which is shorter than that of the prohibition or requirement to which it relates.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Applications for Injunctions
content: A housing provider may make an application only if the application concerns anti-social behaviour that directly or indirectly relates to or affects its housing management functions.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Applications without notice
content: An application for an injunction under section 1 may be made without notice being given to the respondent.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Applications without notice
content: If an application is made without notice the court must eitherâ(a) adjourn the proceedings and grant an interim injunction (see section 7), or (b) adjourn the proceedings without granting an interim injunction, or (c) dismiss the application.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Interim injunctions
content: This section applies where the court adjourns the hearing of an application (whether made with notice or without) for an injunction under section 1.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Interim injunctions
content: The court may grant an injunction under that section lasting until the final hearing of the application or until further order (an âinterim injunctionâ) if the court thinks it just to do so.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Interim injunctions
content: An interim injunction made at a hearing of which the respondent was not given notice may not have the effect of requiring the respondent to participate in particular activities.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Interim injunctions
content: Subject to that, the court has the same powers (including powers under section 4) whether or not the injunction is an interim injunction.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Variation or discharge of injunction
content: The court may vary or discharge an injunction under section 1 on the application ofâ(a) the person who applied for the injunction, or (b) the respondent.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Variation or discharge of injunction
content: In subsection (1) âthe courtâ meansâ(a) the court that granted the injunction, except where paragraph (b) applies; (b) the county court, where the injunction was granted by a youth court but the respondent is aged 18 or over.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Variation or discharge of injunction
content: The power to vary an injunction includes powerâ(a) to include an additional prohibition or requirement in the injunction, or to extend the period for which a prohibition or requirement has effect; (b) to attach a power of arrest, or to extend the period for which a power of arrest has effect.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Variation or discharge of injunction
content: If an application under this section is dismissed, the party by which the dismissed application was made may make no further application under this section withoutâ(a) the consent of the court, or (b) the agreement of the other party.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Variation or discharge of injunction
content: Section 3 applies to additional requirements included under subsection (3)(a) above as it applies to requirements included in a new injunction.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Arrest without warrant
content: Where a power of arrest is attached to a provision of an injunction under section 1, a constable may arrest the respondent without warrant if he or she has reasonable cause to suspect that the respondent is in breach of the provision.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Arrest without warrant
content: A constable who arrests a person under subsection (1) must inform the person who applied for the injunction.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Arrest without warrant
content: A person arrested under subsection (1) must, within the period of 24 hours beginning with the time of the arrest, be brought beforeâ(a) a judge of the High Court or a judge of the county court, if the injunction was granted by the High Court; (b) a judge of the county court, ifâ(i) the injunction was granted by the county court, or (ii) the injunction was granted by a youth court but the respondent is aged 18 or over; (c) a justice of the peace, if neither paragraph (a) nor paragraph (b) applies.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Arrest without warrant
content: In calculating when the period of 24 hours ends, Christmas Day, Good Friday and any Sunday are to be disregarded.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Arrest without warrant
content: The judge before whom a person is brought under subsection (3)(a) or (b) may remand the person if the matter is not disposed of straight away.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Arrest without warrant
content: The justice of the peace before whom a person is brought under subsection (3)(c) must remand the person to appear before the youth court that granted the injunction.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Issue of arrest warrant
content: If the person who applied for an injunction under section 1 thinks that the respondent is in breach of any of its provisions, the person may apply for the issue of a warrant for the respondent's arrest.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Issue of arrest warrant
content: The application must be made toâ(a) a judge of the High Court, if the injunction was granted by the High Court; (b) a judge of the county court, ifâ(i) the injunction was granted by the county court, or (ii) the injunction was granted by a youth court but the respondent is aged 18 or over; (c) a justice of the peace, if neither paragraph (a) nor paragraph (b) applies.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Issue of arrest warrant
content: A judge or justice may issue a warrant under this section only if the judge or justice has reasonable grounds for believing that the respondent is in breach of a provision of the injunction.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Issue of arrest warrant
content: A warrant issued by a judge of the High Court must require the respondent to be brought before that court.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Issue of arrest warrant
content: A warrant issued by a judge of the county court must require the respondent to be brought before that court.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Issue of arrest warrant
content: A warrant issued by a justice of the peace must require the respondent to be brought beforeâ(a) the youth court that granted the injunction, if the person is aged under 18; (b) the county court, if the person is aged 18 or over.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Issue of arrest warrant
content: A constable who arrests a person under a warrant issued under this section must inform the person who applied for the injunction.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Issue of arrest warrant
content: If the respondent is brought before a court by virtue of a warrant under this section but the matter is not disposed of straight away, the court may remand the respondent.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to exclude person from home in cases of violence or risk of harm
content: An injunction under section 1 may have the effect of excluding the respondent from the place where he or she normally lives (âthe premisesâ) only ifâ(a) the respondent is aged 18 or over, (b) the injunction is granted on the application ofâ(i) a local authority, (ii) the chief officer of police for the police area that the premises are in, or (iii) if the premises are owned or managed by a housing provider, that housing provider, and (c) the court thinks thatâ(i) the anti-social behaviour in which the respondent has engaged or threatens to engage consists of or includes the use or threatened use of violence against other persons, or (ii) there is a significant risk of harm to other persons from the respondent.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to exclude person from home in cases of violence or risk of harm
content: For the purposes of this section a housing provider owns a place ifâ(a) the housing provider is a person (other than a mortgagee not in possession) entitled to dispose of the fee simple of the place, whether in possession or in reversion, or (b) the housing provider is a person who holds or is entitled to the rents and profits of the place under a lease that (when granted) was for a term of not less than 3 years.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Requirements to consult etc
content: A person applying for an injunction under section 1 must before doing soâ(a) consult the local youth offending team about the application, if the respondent will be aged under 18 when the application is made; (b) inform any other body or individual the applicant thinks appropriate of the application. This subsection does not apply to a without-notice application.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Requirements to consult etc
content: Where the court adjourns a without-notice application, before the date of the first on-notice hearing the applicant mustâ(a) consult the local youth offending team about the application, if the respondent will be aged under 18 on that date; (b) inform any other body or individual the applicant thinks appropriate of the application.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Requirements to consult etc
content: A person applying for variation or discharge of an injunction under section 1 granted on that person's application must before doing soâ(a) consult the local youth offending team about the application for variation or discharge, if the respondent will be aged under 18 when that application is made; (b) inform any other body or individual the applicant thinks appropriate of that application.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue notices
content: An authorised person may issue a community protection notice to an individual aged 16 or over, or a body, if satisfied on reasonable grounds thatâ(a) the conduct of the individual or body is having a detrimental effect, of a persistent or continuing nature, on the quality of life of those in the locality, and (b) the conduct is unreasonable.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue notices
content: In subsection (1) 'authorised person' means a person on whom section 53 (or an enactment amended by that section) confers power to issue community protection notices.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue notices
content: A community protection notice is a notice that imposes any of the following requirements on the individual or body issued with itâ(a) a requirement to stop doing specified things; (b) a requirement to do specified things; (c) a requirement to take reasonable steps to achieve specified results.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue notices
content: The only requirements that may be imposed are ones that are reasonable to impose in orderâ(a) to prevent the detrimental effect referred to in subsection (1) from continuing or recurring, or (b) to reduce that detrimental effect or to reduce the risk of its continuance or recurrence.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue notices
content: A person (A) may issue a community protection notice to an individual or body (B) only ifâ(a) B has been given a written warning that the notice will be issued unless Bâs conduct ceases to have the detrimental effect referred to in subsection (1), and (b) A is satisfied that, despite B having had enough time to deal with the matter, B's conduct is still having that effect.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue notices
content: A person issuing a community protection notice must before doing so inform any body or individual the person thinks appropriate.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue notices
content: A community protection notice mustâ(a) identify the conduct referred to in subsection (1); (b) explain the effect of sections 46 to 51.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue notices
content: A community protection notice may specify periods within which, or times by which, requirements within subsection (3)(b) or (c) are to be complied with.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Occupiers of premises etc
content: Conduct on, or affecting, premises (other than premises within subsection (2)) that a particular personâ(a) owns, (b) leases, (c) occupies, (d) controls, (e) operates, or (f) maintains, is treated for the purposes of section 43 as conduct of that person.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Occupiers of premises etc
content: Conduct on, or affecting, premises occupied for the purposes of a government department is treated for the purposes of section 43 as conduct of the Minister in charge of that department.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Occupiers of premises etc
content: This section does not treat an individual's conduct as that of another person if that person cannot reasonably be expected to control or affect it.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Occupier or owner unascertainable
content: This section applies whereâ(a) an authorised person has power to issue a community protection notice, (b) the detrimental effect referred to in section 43(1) arises from the condition of premises or the use to which premises have been put, and (c) the authorised person has made reasonable enquiries to find out the name or proper address of the occupier of the premises (or, if the premises are unoccupied, the owner) but without success.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Occupier or owner unascertainable
content: The authorised person mayâ(a) post the community protection notice on the premises; (b) enter the premises, or other premises, to the extent reasonably necessary for that purpose.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Occupier or owner unascertainable
content: The community protection notice is treated as having been issued to the occupier of the premises (or, if the premises are unoccupied, the owner) at the time the notice is posted.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Occupier or owner unascertainable
content: In this section âauthorised personâ has the same meaning as in section 43(1).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Appeals against notices
content: A person issued with a community protection notice may appeal to a magistrates' court against the notice on any of the following grounds: (1) That the conduct specified in the community protection noticeâ(a) did not take place, (b) has not had a detrimental effect on the quality of life of those in the locality, (c) has not been of a persistent or continuing nature, (d) is not unreasonable, or (e) is conduct that the person cannot reasonably be expected to control or affect; (2) That any of the requirements in the notice, or any of the periods within which or times by which they are to be complied with, are unreasonable; (3) That there is a material defect or error in, or in connection with, the notice; (4) That the notice was issued to the wrong person.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Appeals against notices
content: An appeal must be made within the period of 21 days beginning with the day on which the person is issued with the notice.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Appeals against notices
content: While an appeal against a community protection notice is in progressâ(a) a requirement imposed by the notice to stop doing specified things remains in effect, unless the court orders otherwise; (b) any other requirement imposed by the notice is of no effect. For this purpose an appeal is âin progressâ until it is finally determined or is withdrawn.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Appeals against notices
content: A magistrates' court hearing an appeal against a community protection notice mustâ(a) quash the notice, (b) modify the notice (for example by extending a period specified in it), or (c) dismiss the appeal.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial action by local authority
content: Where a person issued with a community protection notice (âthe defaulterâ) fails to comply with a requirement of the notice, the relevant local authority may take action under subsection (2) or subsection (3) (or both).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial action by local authority
content: The relevant local authority may have work carried out to ensure that the failure is remedied, but only on land that is open to the air.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial action by local authority
content: As regards premises other than land open to the air, if the relevant local authority issues the defaulter with a noticeâ(a) specifying work it intends to have carried out to ensure that the failure is remedied, (b) specifying the estimated cost of the work, and (c) inviting the defaulter to consent to the work being carried out, the authority may have the work carried out if the necessary consent is given.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial action by local authority
content: In subsection (3) âthe necessary consentâ means the consent ofâ(a) the defaulter, and (b) the owner of the premises on which the work is to be carried out (if that is not the defaulter). Paragraph (b) does not apply where the relevant authority has made reasonable efforts to contact the owner of the premises but without success.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial action by local authority
content: A person authorised by a local authority to carry out work under this section may enter any premises to the extent reasonably necessary for that purpose, except that a person who is only authorised to carry out work under subsection (2) may only enter land that is open to the air.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial action by local authority
content: If work is carried out under subsection (2) or (3) and the relevant local authority issues a notice to the defaulterâ(a) giving details of the work that was carried out, and (b) specifying an amount that is no more than the cost to the authority of having the work carried out, the defaulter is liable to the authority for that amount (subject to the outcome of any appeal under subsection (7)).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial action by local authority
content: A person issued with a notice under subsection (6) may appeal to a magistrates' court, within the period of 21 days beginning with the day on which the notice was issued, on the ground that the amount specified under subsection (6)(b) is excessive.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial action by local authority
content: A magistrates' court hearing an appeal under subsection (7) mustâ(a) confirm the amount, or (b) substitute a lower amount.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial action by local authority
content: In this section 'the relevant local authority' meansâ(a) the local authority that issued the community protection notice; (b) if the community protection notice was not issued by a local authority, the local authority (or, as the case may be, one of the local authorities) that could have issued it.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Offence of failing to comply with notice
content: A person issued with a community protection notice who fails to comply with it commits an offence.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Offence of failing to comply with notice
content: A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summary convictionâ(a) to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale, in the case of an individual; (b) to [F1 a fine], in the case of a body.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Offence of failing to comply with notice
content: A person does not commit an offence under this section ifâ(a) the person took all reasonable steps to comply with the notice, or (b) there is some other reasonable excuse for the failure to comply with it.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial orders
content: A court before which a person is convicted of an offence under section 48 in respect of a community protection notice may make whatever order the court thinks appropriate for ensuring that what the notice requires to be done is done.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial orders
content: An order under this section may in particular require the defendantâ(a) to carry out specified work, or (b) to allow specified work to be carried out by or on behalf of a specified local authority.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial orders
content: To be specified under subsection (2)(b) a local authority must beâ(a) the local authority that issued the community protection notice; (b) if the community protection notice was not issued by a local authority the local authority (or, as the case may be, one of the local authorities) that could have issued it.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial orders
content: A requirement imposed under subsection (2)(b) does not authorise the person carrying out the work to enter the defendant's home without the defendant's consent. But this does not prevent a defendant who fails to give that consent from being in breach of the court's order.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial orders
content: In subsection (4) âthe defendant's homeâ means the house, flat, vehicle or other accommodation where the defendantâ(a) usually lives, or (b) is living at the time when the work is or would be carried out.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Remedial orders
content: If work is carried out under subsection (2)(b) and the local authority specified under that subsection issues a notice to the defaulterâ(a) giving details of the work that was carried out, and (b) specifying an amount that is no more than the cost to the authority of having the work carried out, the defaulter is liable to the authority for that amount (subject to the outcome of any appeal under subsection (7)).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: An authorised person may issue a fixed penalty notice to anyone who that person has reason to believe has committed an offence under section 48.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: In subsection (1) "authorised person" means a person on whom section 53 (or an enactment amended by that section) confers power to issue fixed penalty notices under this section.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: A fixed penalty notice is a notice offering the person to whom it is issued the opportunity of discharging any liability to conviction for the offence by payment of a fixed penalty to a local authority specified in the notice.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: The local authority specified under subsection (3) must beâ(a) the local authority that issued the community protection notice to which the fixed penalty notice relates; (b) if the community protection notice was not issued by a local authority, the local authority (or, as the case may be, one of the local authorities) that could have issued it.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: Where a person is issued with a notice under this section in respect of an offenceâ(a) no proceedings may be taken for the offence before the end of the period of 14 days following the date of the notice; (b) the person may not be convicted of the offence if the person pays the fixed penalty before the end of that period.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: A fixed penalty notice mustâ(a) give reasonably detailed particulars of the circumstances alleged to constitute the offence; (b) state the period during which (because of subsection (5)(a)) proceedings will not be taken for the offence; (c) specify the amount of the fixed penalty; (d) state the name and address of the person to whom the fixed penalty may be paid; (e) specify permissible methods of payment.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: An amount specified under subsection (6)(c) must not be more than Â£100.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: A fixed penalty notice may specify two amounts under subsection (6)(c) and specify that, if the lower of those amounts is paid within a specified period (of less than 14 days), that is the amount of the fixed penalty.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: Whatever other method may be specified under subsection (6)(e), payment of a fixed penalty may be made by pre-paying and posting to the person whose name is stated under subsection (6)(d), at the stated address, a letter containing the amount of the penalty (in cash or otherwise).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: Where a letter is sent as mentioned in subsection (9), payment is regarded as having been made at the time at which that letter would be delivered in the ordinary course of post.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: In any proceedings, a certificate thatâ(a) purports to be signed by or on behalf of the chief finance officer of the local authority concerned, and (b) states that payment of a fixed penalty was, or was not, received by the date specified in the certificate, is evidence of the facts stated.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Fixed penalty notices
content: In this section âchief finance officerâ, in relation to a local authority, means the person with responsibility for the authority's financial affairs.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue closure notices
content: A police officer of at least the rank of inspector, or the local authority, may issue a closure notice if satisfied on reasonable groundsâ(a) that the use of particular premises has resulted, or (if the notice is not issued) is likely soon to result, in nuisance to members of the public, or (b) that there has been, or (if the notice is not issued) is likely soon to be, disorder near those premises associated with the use of those premises, and that the notice is necessary to prevent the nuisance or disorder from continuing, recurring or occurring.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue closure notices
content: A closure notice is a notice prohibiting access to the premises for a period specified in the notice. For the maximum period, see section 77.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue closure notices
content: A closure notice may prohibit accessâ(a) by all persons except those specified, or by all persons except those of a specified description; (b) at all times, or at all times except those specified; (c) in all circumstances, or in all circumstances except those specified.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue closure notices
content: A closure notice may not prohibit access byâ(a) people who habitually live on the premises, or (b) the owner of the premises, and accordingly they must be specified under subsection (3)(a).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue closure notices
content: A closure notice mustâ(a) identify the premises; (b) explain the effect of the notice; (c) state that failure to comply with the notice is an offence; (d) state that an application will be made under section 80 for a closure order; (e) specify when and where the application will be heard; (f) explain the effect of a closure order; (g) give information about the names of, and means of contacting, persons and organisations in the area that provide advice about housing and legal matters.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue closure notices
content: A closure notice may be issued only if reasonable efforts have been made to informâ(a) people who live on the premises (whether habitually or not), and (b) any person who has control of or responsibility for the premises or who has an interest in them, that the notice is going to be issued.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue closure notices
content: Before issuing a closure notice the police officer or local authority must ensure that any body or individual the officer or authority thinks appropriate has been consulted.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Power to issue closure notices
content: The Secretary of State may by regulations specify premises or descriptions of premises in relation to which a closure notice may not be issued.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Cancellation or variation of closure notices
content: This section applies where a closure notice is in force and the relevant officer or authority is no longer satisfied as mentioned in section 76(1), eitherâ (a) as regards the premises as a whole, or (b) as regards a particular part of the premises.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Cancellation or variation of closure notices
content: In a case within subsection (1)(a) the relevant officer or authority must issue a cancellation notice.  A cancellation notice is a notice cancelling the closure notice.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Cancellation or variation of closure notices
content: In a case within subsection (1)(b) the relevant officer or authority must issue a variation notice.  A variation notice is a notice varying the closure notice so that it does not apply to the part of the premises referred to in subsection (1)(b).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Cancellation or variation of closure notices
content: A cancellation notice or a variation notice that relates to a closure notice which wasâ (a) issued by a local authority, and (b) signed as mentioned in section 77(2)(b),  must be signed by the person who signed the closure notice (or, if that person is not available, by another person who could have signed as mentioned in section 77(2)(b)).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Cancellation or variation of closure notices
content: A cancellation notice or a variation notice that relates to a closure notice which wasâ (a) issued by a local authority, and (b) extended under section 77(4)(b),  must be signed by the person who signed the extension notice (or, if that person is not available, by another person who could have signed the extension notice).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Cancellation or variation of closure notices
content: In this section âthe relevant officer or authorityâ meansâ (a) in the case of a closure notice issued by a police officer and not extended under section 77(4)(a), that officer (or, if that officer is not available, another officer of the same or higher rank); (b) in the case of a closure notice issued by a police officer and extended under section 77(4)(a), the officer who issued the extension notice (or, if that officer is not available, another officer of the same or higher rank); (c) in the case of a closure notice issued by a local authority, that authority.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: If the court is satisfied that any of the following conditions is met, it must make an order for the possession of a dwelling-house let under a secure tenancy.  This is subject to subsection (2) (and to any available defence based on the tenant's Convention rights, within the meaning of the Human Rights Act 1998).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: Subsection (1) applies only where the landlord has complied with any obligations it has under section 85ZA (review of decision to seek possession).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: Condition 1 is thatâ (a) the tenant, or a person residing in or visiting the dwelling-house, has been convicted of a serious offence, and (b) the serious offenceâ     (i) was committed (wholly or partly) in, or in the locality of, the dwelling-house,     (ii) was committed elsewhere against a person with a right (of whatever description) to reside in, or occupy housing accommodation in the locality of, the dwelling-house, or     (iii) was committed elsewhere against the landlord of the dwelling-house, or a person employed (whether or not by the landlord) in connection with the exercise of the landlord's housing management functions, and directly or indirectly related to or affected those functions.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: Condition 2 is that a court has found in relevant proceedings that the tenant, or a person residing in or visiting the dwelling-house, has breached a provision of an injunction under sectionÂ 1 of the Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing ActÂ 2014, other than a provision requiring a person to participate in a particular activity, andâ (a) the breach occurred in, or in the locality of, the dwelling-house, or (b) the breach occurred elsewhere and the provision breached was a provision intended to preventâ     (i) conduct that is capable of causing nuisance or annoyance to a person with a right (of whatever description) to reside in, or occupy housing accommodation in the locality of, the dwelling-house, or     (ii) conduct that is capable of causing nuisance or annoyance to the landlord of the dwelling-house, or a person employed (whether or not by the landlord) in connection with the exercise of the landlord's housing management functions, and that is directly or indirectly related to or affects those functions.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: Condition 3 is that the tenant, or a person residing in or visiting the dwelling-house, has been convicted of an offence under section 30 of the Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014 consisting of a breach of a provision of a criminal behaviour order prohibiting a person from doing anything described in the order, and the offence involvedâ (a) a breach that occurred in, or in the locality of, the dwelling-house, or (b) a breach that occurred elsewhere of a provision intended to preventâ     (i) behaviour that causes or is likely to cause harassment, alarm or distress to a person with a right (of whatever description) to reside in, or occupy housing accommodation in the locality of, the dwelling-house, or     (ii) behaviour that causes or is likely to cause harassment, alarm or distress to the landlord of the dwelling-house, or a person employed (whether or not by the landlord) in connection with the exercise of the landlord's housing management functions, and that is directly or indirectly related to or affects those functions.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: Condition 4 is thatâ (a) the dwelling-house is or has been subject to a closure order under section 80 of the Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014, and (b) access to the dwelling-house has been prohibited (under the closure order or under a closure notice issued under section 76 of that Act) for a continuous period of more than 48 hours.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: Condition 5 is thatâ (a) the tenant, or a person residing in or visiting the dwelling-house, has been convicted of an offence underâ     (i) section 80(4) of the Environmental Protection Act 1990 (breach of abatement notice in relation to statutory nuisance), or     (ii) section 82(8) of that Act (breach of court order to abate statutory nuisance etc.), and (b) the nuisance concerned was noise emitted from the dwelling-house which was a statutory nuisance for the purposes of Part 3 of that Act by virtue of section 79(1)(g) of that Act (noise emitted from premises so as to be prejudicial to health or a nuisance).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: Condition 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5 is not met ifâ (a) there is an appeal against the conviction, finding or order concerned which has not been finally determined, abandoned or withdrawn, or (b) the final determination of the appeal results in the conviction, finding or order being overturned.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: In this sectionâ ârelevant proceedingsâ means proceedings for contempt of court or proceedings under Schedule 2 to the Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014; âserious offenceâ means an offence whichâ (a) was committed on or after the day on which subsection (3) comes into force, (b) is specified, or falls within a description specified, in Schedule 2A at the time the offence was committed and at the time the court is considering the matter, and (c) is not an offence that is triable only summarily by virtue of section 22 of the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 (either-way offences where value involved is small).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: The Secretary of State may by order amend Schedule 2A as it applies in relation to dwelling-houses in England byâ (a) adding an indictable offence; (b) removing an offence.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: The Welsh Ministers may by order amend Schedule 2A as it applies in relation to dwelling-houses in Wales byâ (a) adding an indictable offence; (b) removing an offence.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: An order under subsection (10) or (11)â (a) is to be made by statutory instrument; (b) may make different provision for different purposes; (c) may include incidental, supplementary, consequential, transitional or saving provision.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour
content: A statutory instrument containing an order under subsection (10) or (11) may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before and approved by a resolution ofâ (a) each House of Parliament (in the case of an order of the Secretary of State), or (b) the National Assembly for Wales (in the case of an order of the Welsh Ministers).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: This section applies in relation to proceedings for possession of a dwellingâhouse under section 84A (absolute ground for possession for antiâsocial behaviour), including proceedings where possession is also sought on one or more of the grounds set out in ScheduleÂ 2.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: The court must not entertain the proceedings unless the landlord has served on the tenant a notice under this section.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: The notice mustâ (a) state that the court will be asked to make an order under section 84A for the possession of the dwellingâhouse, (b) set out the reasons for the landlord's decision to apply for the order (including the condition or conditions in section 84A on which the landlord proposes to rely), and (c) inform the tenant of any right that the tenant may have under section 85ZA to request a review of the landlord's decision and of the time within which the request must be made.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: In a case where possession is also sought on one or more of the grounds set out in ScheduleÂ 2, the notice must alsoâ (a) specify the ground on which the court will be asked to make the order, and (b) give particulars of that ground.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: A notice which states that the landlord proposes to rely upon conditionÂ 1,Â 3 orÂ 5 in sectionÂ 84Aâ (a) must also state the conviction on which the landlord proposes to rely, and (b) must be served on the tenant withinâ     (i) the period of 12Â months beginning with the day of the conviction, or     (ii) if there is an appeal against the conviction, the period of 12Â months beginning with the day on which the appeal is finally determined or abandoned.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: A notice which states that the landlord proposes to rely upon conditionÂ 2 in sectionÂ 84Aâ (a) must also state the finding on which the landlord proposes to rely, and (b) must be served on the tenant withinâ     (i) the period of 12Â months beginning with the day on which the court has made the finding, or     (ii) if there is an appeal against the finding, the period of 12Â months beginning with the day on which the appeal is finally determined, abandoned or withdrawn.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: A notice which states that the landlord proposes to rely upon condition 4 in section 84Aâ (a) must also state the closure order concerned, and (b) must be served on the tenant withinâ     (i) the period of 3 months beginning with the day on which the closure order was made, or     (ii) if there is an appeal against the making of the order, the period of 3 months beginning with the day on which the appeal is finally determined, abandoned or withdrawn.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: A notice under this section must also inform the tenant that, if the tenant needs help or advice about the notice and what to do about it, the tenant should take it immediately to a Citizensâ Advice Bureau, a housing aid centre, a law centre or a solicitor.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: The noticeâ (a) must also specify the date after which proceedings for the possession of the dwellingâhouse may be begun, and (b) ceases to be in force 12 months after the date so specified.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: The date specified in accordance with subsection (9)(a) must not be earlier thanâ (a) in the case of a periodic tenancy, the date on which the tenancy could, apart from this Part, be brought to an end by notice to quit given by the landlord on the same day as the notice under this section; (b) in the case of a secure tenancy for a term certain, one month after the date of the service of the notice.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Notice requirements in relation to proceedings for possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: Where a notice under this section is served with respect to a secure tenancy for a term certain, it has effect also with respect to any periodic tenancy arising on the termination of that tenancy by virtue of section 86; and subsection (10)(a) does not apply to the notice.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Review of decision to seek possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: A tenant may request a review of a landlord's decision to seek an order for possession of a dwelling-house under section 84A if the interest of the landlord belongs toâ (a) a local housing authority, or (b) a housing action trust.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Review of decision to seek possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: Such a request must be made in writing before the end of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the notice under section 83ZA is served.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Review of decision to seek possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: On a request being duly made to it, the landlord must review its decision.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Review of decision to seek possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: The landlord must notify the tenant in writing of the decision on the review.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Review of decision to seek possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: If the decision is to confirm the original decision, the landlord must also notify the tenant of the reasons for the decision.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Review of decision to seek possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: The review must be carried out, and the tenant notified, before the day specified in the notice under section 83ZA as the day after which proceedings for the possession of the dwelling-house may be begun.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Review of decision to seek possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the procedure to be followed in connection with a review under this section that relates to an order for possession of a dwelling-house in England.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Review of decision to seek possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: The Welsh Ministers may by regulations make provision about the procedure to be followed in connection with a review under this section that relates to an order for possession of a dwelling-house in Wales.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Review of decision to seek possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: Regulations under subsections (7) and (8) may, in particular, make provisionâ (a) requiring the decision on review to be made by a person of appropriate seniority who was not involved in the original decision, and (b) as to the circumstances in which the person concerned is entitled to be represented or to be accompanied in proceedings for the review by another person.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Review of decision to seek possession on absolute ground for anti-social behaviour
content: Regulations under this sectionâ (a) may contain transitional or saving provision; (b) are to be made by statutory instrument whichâ     (i) in the case of regulations made by the Secretary of State, is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament;     (ii) in the case of regulations made by the Welsh Ministers, is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of the National Assembly for Wales.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Conduct causing nuisance to landlord etc
content: has been guilty of conduct causing or likely to cause a nuisance or annoyance to the landlord of the dwellingâhouse, or a person employed (whether or not by the landlord) in connection with the exercise of the landlord's housing management functions, and that is directly or indirectly related to or affects those functions.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Offences connected with riot
content: The tenant or an adult residing in the dwelling-house has been convicted of an indictable offence which took place during, and at the scene of, a riot in the United Kingdom.  In this Groundâ âadultâ means a person aged 18 or over; âindictable offenceâ does not include an offence that is triable only summarily by virtue of section 22 of the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 (either-way offences where value involved is small); âriotâ is to be construed in accordance with section 1 of the Public Order Act 1986.  This Ground applies only in relation to dwelling-houses in England.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: The community remedy document
content: Each local policing body must prepare a community remedy document for its area, and may revise it at any time.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: The community remedy document
content: A community remedy document is a list of actions any of which might, in the opinion of the local policing body, be appropriate in a particular case to be carried out by a person whoâ (a) has engaged in anti-social behaviour or has committed an offence, and (b) is to be dealt with for that behaviour or offence without court proceedings.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: The community remedy document
content: For the purposes of subsection (2), an action is appropriate to be carried out by a person only if it has one or more of the following objectsâ (a) assisting in the person's rehabilitation; (b) ensuring that the person makes reparation for the behaviour or offence in question; (c) punishing the person.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: The community remedy document
content: In preparing or revising the community remedy document for its area a local policing body mustâ (a) have regard to the need to promote public confidence in the out-of-court disposal process; (b) have regard to any guidance issued by the Secretary of State about how local policing bodies are to discharge their functions under this section; (c) carry out the necessary consultation and take account of all views expressed by those consulted.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: The community remedy document
content: In subsection (4)(c) âthe necessary consultationâ meansâ (a) consultation with the chief officer of police for the area, (b) consultation with the local authority for any part of the area, (c) consultation with whatever community representatives the local policing body thinks it appropriate to consult, (d) whatever other public consultation the local policing body thinks appropriate.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: The community remedy document
content: A local policing body must agree the community remedy document for its area, and any revised document, with the chief officer of police for the area.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: The community remedy document
content: Once the community remedy document, or a revised document, has been agreed with the chief officer of police, the local policing body must publish it in whatever way it thinks appropriate.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: The community remedy document
content: The Secretary of State must publish any guidance issued under subsection (4)(b).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: The community remedy document
content: In this sectionâ âanti-social behaviourâ has the meaning given by section 2 (ignoring subsection (2) of that section); âcommunity representativeâ, in relation to a police area, means any individual or body appearing to the local policing body to represent the views of people who live in, work in or visit the area; âlocal authorityâ meansâ     (a) in relation to England, a district council, a county council for an area for which there is no district council, a London borough council, the Common Council of the City of London or the Council of the Isles of Scilly;     (b) in relation to Wales, a county council or a county borough council; âout-of-court disposal processâ means the process by which a person is dealt with under section 102 or by means of a conditional caution or youth conditional caution.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Anti-social behaviour etc: out-of-court disposals
content: This section applies whereâ (a) a person (P) within subsection (2) has evidence that an individual (A) has engaged in anti-social behaviour or committed an offence, (b) A admits to P that he or she has done so, (c) P thinks that the evidence is enough for taking proceedings against A for an injunction under section 1, or taking other court proceedings, but decides that it would be appropriate for A to carry out action of some sort instead, and (d) if the evidence is that A has committed an offence, P does not think that it would be more appropriate for A to be given a caution or a fixed penalty notice.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Anti-social behaviour etc: out-of-court disposals
content: The persons within this subsection areâ (a) a constable; (b) an investigating officer; (c) a person authorised by a relevant prosecutor for the purposes of section 22 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (conditional cautions) or section 66A of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998 (youth conditional cautions).

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Anti-social behaviour etc: out-of-court disposals
content: Before deciding what action to invite A to carry out, P must make reasonable efforts to obtain the views of the victim (if any) of the anti-social behaviour or the offence, and in particular the victim's views as to whether A should carry out any of the actions listed in the community remedy document.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Anti-social behaviour etc: out-of-court disposals
content: If the victim expresses the view that A should carry out a particular action listed in the community remedy document, P must invite A to carry out that action unless it seems to P that it would be inappropriate to do so.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Anti-social behaviour etc: out-of-court disposals
content: Whereâ (a) there is more than one victim and they express different views, or (b) for any other reason subsection (4) does not apply, P must nevertheless take account of any views expressed by the victim (or victims) in deciding what action to invite A to carry out.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Anti-social behaviour etc: out-of-court disposals
content: In this sectionâ âactionâ includes the making of a payment to the victim (but does not include the payment of a fixed penalty); âanti-social behaviourâ has the meaning given by section 2 (ignoring subsection (2) of that section); âcommunity remedy documentâ means the community remedy document (as revised from time to time) published under section 101 for the police area in which A's anti-social behaviour or offence took place; âcautionââ     (a) in the case of a person aged 18 or over, includes a conditional caution within the meaning of Part 3 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003;     (b) in the case of a person under that age, means a youth caution or youth conditional caution within the meaning of Chapter 1 of Part 4 of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998; âinvestigating officerâ and ârelevant prosecutorâ have the same meaning as in Part 3 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (see section 27 of that Act); âvictimâ means the particular person who seems to P to have been affected, or principally affected, by A's anti-social behaviour or offence.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
heading: Review of response to complaints
content: In a case where a person has made a complaint about anti-social behaviour in a particular local government area, the relevant bodies in that area must carry out a review of the response to that behaviour (an âASB case reviewâ) ifâ (a) that person, or any other person, makes an application for such a review, and (b) the relevant bodies decide that the threshold for a review is met.

title: Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2014
