content: (7) Where a notice under section 13(2) above has been referred to [F10 the appropriate tribunal], then, unless the landlord and the tenant otherwise agree, the rent determined by [F11 the appropriate tribunal] (subject in a case where subsection (5) above applies, to the addition of the appropriate amount in respect of rates) shall be the rent under the tenancy with effect from the beginning of the new period specified in the notice or, if it appears to [F12 the appropriate tribunal] that that would cause undue hardship to the tenant, with effect from such later date (not being later than the date the rent is determined) as [F11 the appropriate tribunal] may direct.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Determination of rent for dwelling-houses
content: (8) Nothing in this section requires [F13 the appropriate tribunal] to continue with their determination of a rent for a dwelling-house if the landlord and tenant give notice in writing that they no longer require such a determination or if the tenancy has come to an end.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Determination of rent for dwelling-houses
content: (9) This section shall apply in relation to an assured shorthold tenancy as if in subsection (1) the reference to an assured tenancy were a reference to an assured shorthold tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Security of tenure
content: An assured tenancy cannot be brought to an end by the landlord except byâ (a) obtainingâ    (i) an order of the court for possession of the dwelling-house under section 7 or 21, and    (ii) the execution of the order, (b) obtaining an order of the court under section 6A (demotion order), (c) in the case of a fixed term tenancy which contains power for the landlord to determine the tenancy in certain circumstances, by the exercise of that power, or (d) in the case of an assured tenancyâ    (i) which is a residential tenancy agreement within the meaning of Chapter 1 of Part 3 of the Immigration Act 2014, and    (ii) in relation to which the condition in section 33D(2) of that Act is met, giving a notice in accordance with that section, and accordingly, the service by the landlord of a notice to quit is of no effect in relation to a periodic assured tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Security of tenure
content: Where an order of the court for possession of the dwelling-house is obtained, the tenancy ends when the order is executed.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Security of tenure
content: If an assured tenancy which is a fixed term tenancy comes to an end otherwise than by virtue ofâ (a) an order of the court of the kind mentioned in subsection (1)(a) or (b) or any other order of the court, (b) a surrender or other action on the part of the tenant, or (c) the giving of a notice under sectionÂ 33D of the Immigration ActÂ 2014, then, subject to section 7 and ChapterÂ II below, the tenant shall be entitled to remain in possession of the dwelling-house let under that tenancy and, subject to subsection (4) below, his right to possession shall depend upon a periodic tenancy arising by virtue of this section.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Security of tenure
content: The periodic tenancy referred to in subsection (2) above shall not arise if, on the coming to an end of the fixed term tenancy, the tenant is entitled, by virtue of the grant of another tenancy, to possession of the same or substantially the same dwelling-house as was let to him under the fixed term tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Security of tenure
content: If, on or before the date on which a tenancy is entered into or is deemed to have been granted as mentioned in subsection (3)(b) above, the person who is to be the tenant under that tenancyâ (a) enters into an obligation to do any act which (apart from this subsection) will cause the tenancy to come to an end at a time when it is an assured tenancy, or (b) executes, signs or gives any surrender, notice to quit or other document which (apart from this subsection) has the effect of bringing the tenancy to an end at a time when it is an assured tenancy, the obligation referred to in paragraph (a) above shall not be enforceable or, as the case may be, the surrender, notice to quit or other document referred to in paragraph (b) above shall be of no effect.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Security of tenure
content: If, by virtue of any provision of this Part of this Act, Part I of Schedule 1 to this Act has effect in relation to a fixed term tenancy as if it consisted only of paragraphs 11 and 12, that Part shall have the like effect in relation to any periodic tenancy which arises by virtue of this section on the coming to an end of the fixed term tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Security of tenure
content: Any reference in this Part of this Act to a statutory periodic tenancy is a reference to a periodic tenancy arising by virtue of this section.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Fixing of terms of statutory periodic tenancy
content: In this section, in relation to a statutory periodic tenancy,â (a) âthe former tenancyâ means the fixed term tenancy on the coming to an end of which the statutory periodic tenancy arises; and (b) âthe implied termsâ means the terms of the tenancy which have effect by virtue of section 5(3)(e) above, other than terms as to the amount of the rent; but nothing in the following provisions of this section applies to a statutory periodic tenancy at a time when, by virtue of paragraph 11 or paragraph 12 in Part I of Schedule 1 to this Act, it cannot be an assured tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Fixing of terms of statutory periodic tenancy
content: Not later than the first anniversary of the day on which the former tenancy came to an end, the landlord may serve on the tenant, or the tenant may serve on the landlord, a notice in the prescribed form proposing terms of the statutory periodic tenancy different from the implied terms and, if the landlord or the tenant considers it appropriate, proposing an adjustment of the amount of the rent to take account of the proposed terms.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Fixing of terms of statutory periodic tenancy
content: Where a notice has been served under subsection (2) above,â (a) within the period of three months beginning on the date on which the notice was served on him, the landlord or the tenant, as the case may be, may, by an application in the prescribed form, refer the notice to the appropriate tribunal under subsection (4) below; and (b) if the notice is not so referred, then, with effect from such date, not falling within the period referred to in paragraph (a) above, as may be specified in the notice, the terms proposed in the notice shall become terms of the tenancy in substitution for any of the implied terms dealing with the same subject matter and the amount of the rent shall be varied in accordance with any adjustment so proposed.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Fixing of terms of statutory periodic tenancy
content: Where a notice under subsection (2) above is referred to the appropriate tribunal, the tribunal shall consider the terms proposed in the notice and shall determine whether those terms, or some other terms (dealing with the same subject matter as the proposed terms), are such as, in the appropriate tribunalâs opinion, might reasonably be expected to be found in an assured periodic tenancy of the dwellingâhouse concerned, being a tenancyâ (a) which begins on the coming to an end of the former tenancy; and (b) which is granted by a willing landlord on terms which, except in so far as they relate to the subject matter of the proposed terms, are those of the statutory periodic tenancy at the time of the appropriate tribunalâs consideration.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Fixing of terms of statutory periodic tenancy
content: Whether or not a notice under subsection (2) above proposes an adjustment of the amount of the rent under the statutory periodic tenancy, where the appropriate tribunal determine any terms under subsection (4) above, they shall, if they consider it appropriate, specify such an adjustment to take account of the terms so determined.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Fixing of terms of statutory periodic tenancy
content: In making a determination under subsection (4) above, or specifying an adjustment of an amount of rent under subsection (5) above, there shall be disregarded any effect on the terms or the amount of the rent attributable to the granting of a tenancy to a sitting tenant.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Fixing of terms of statutory periodic tenancy
content: Where a notice under subsection (2) above is referred to the appropriate tribunal, then, unless the landlord and the tenant otherwise agree, with effect from such date as the appropriate tribunal may directâ (a) the terms determined by the appropriate tribunal shall become terms of the statutory periodic tenancy in substitution for any of the implied terms dealing with the same subject matter; and (b) the amount of the rent under the statutory periodic tenancy shall be altered to accord with any adjustment specified by the appropriate tribunal; but for the purposes of paragraph (b) above the appropriate tribunal shall not direct a date earlier than the date specified, in accordance with subsection (3)(b) above, in the notice referred to them.

title: Housing Act 1988
heading: Fixing of terms of statutory periodic tenancy
content: Nothing in this section requires the appropriate tribunal to continue with a determination under subsection (4) above if the landlord and tenant give notice in writing that they no longer require such a determination or if the tenancy has come to an end.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Tenancies to which Part VI applies
content: In this Part of this Act âhousing association tenancyâ means a tenancy to which this Part of this Act applies.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Conversion of housing association tenancies into regulated tenancies
content: If at any time, by virtue of subsections (1) and (3) of section 15 of this Act, a tenancy ceases to be one to which this Part of this Act applies and becomes a protected tenancy, that tenancy shall be a regulated tenancy and the housing association which is the landlord under that tenancy shall give notice in writing to the tenant, in such form as may be prescribed, informing him that his tenancy is no longer excluded from protection under this Act.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Conversion of housing association tenancies into regulated tenancies
content: If, without reasonable excuse, a housing association fails to give notice to a tenant under subsection (1) above within the period of 21 days beginning on the day on which his tenancy becomes a protected tenancy, the association shall be liable to a fine not exceeding Â£100.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Conversion of housing association tenancies into regulated tenancies
content: Where an offence under subsection (2) above committed by a body corporate is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of, or to be attributable to any neglect on the part of, any director, manager or secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate or any person who was purporting to act in any such capacity, he as well as the body corporate shall be guilty of that offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Conversion of housing association tenancies into regulated tenancies
content: Schedule 14 to this Act shall have effect for supplementing this section.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Conversion of housing association tenancies into regulated tenancies
content: In this sectionâ  âhousing associationâ has the same meaning as in the Housing Associations Act 1985; and other definitions as applicable.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Increase of rent without notice to quit
content: Subject to subsections (2) and (3) below, where a housing association tenancy is a weekly or other periodical tenancy but not an occupation contract, the rent payable to the housing association or, as the case may be, the housing trust or the Regulator of Social Housing or the Secretary of State in this subsection and subsection (2) called âthe landlordâ may, without the tenancy being terminated, be increased with effect from the beginning of any rental period by a written notice of increase specifying the date on which the increase is to take effect and given by the landlord to the tenant not later than four weeks before that date.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Increase of rent without notice to quit
content: Where notice of increase is given under subsection (1) above and the tenant, before the date specified in the notice of increase, gives a valid notice to quit, the notice of increase does not take effect unless the tenant, with the written agreement of the landlord, withdraws his notice to quit before that date.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Increase of rent without notice to quit
content: Where a housing association tenancy is a secure contract or a periodic standard contract, the rent payable to the housing association or, as the case may be, the housing trust or the Welsh Ministers in this subsection called âthe landlordâ may be increased with effect from the beginning of any rental period by a written notice of increase specifying the date on which the increase is to take effect, and given by the landlord to the contract-holder not later than four weeks before that date.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Increase of rent without notice to quit
content: A notice of increase given under subsection (2A) does not take effect if, before the date specified in that notice, the contract-holder gives a notice to end the contract.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Increase of rent without notice to quit
content: But the notice of increase does take effect if, before the date specified in that notice, the notice to end the contract ceases to have effect (see section 167(3) or 172(3) of the Renting Homes (Wales) Act 2016 (anaw 1)).

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Increase of rent without notice to quit
content: This section shall apply to a tenancy notwithstanding that the letting took place before the coming into force of this Act.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Increase of rent without notice to quit
content: Nothing in this section shall authorise any rent to be increased above the rent limit, and any reference in section 88 of this Act to the variation by agreement of the rent recoverable under a tenancy shall include a reference to variation under this section.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Increase of rent without notice to quit
content: In this section, the following terms have the same meaning as in the Renting Homes (Wales) 2016 (anaw 1) (see sections 7 and 8 of that Act):  - contract-holder; - occupation contract; - periodic standard contract; - secure contract;  and ânotice to end the contractâ means a notice under section 163 or 168 of that Act.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Recovery from landlord of sums paid in excess of recoverable rent, etc
content: Where a tenant has paid on account of rent any amount which, by virtue of this Part of this Act, is irrecoverable by the landlord, the tenant who paid it shall be entitled to recover that amount from the landlord who received it or his personal representatives.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Recovery from landlord of sums paid in excess of recoverable rent, etc
content: Any amount which a tenant is entitled to recover under subsection (1) above may without prejudice to any other method of recovery, be deducted by the tenant from any rent payable by him to the landlord.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Recovery from landlord of sums paid in excess of recoverable rent, etc
content: No amount which a tenant is entitled to recover under subsection (1) above shall be recoverable at any time after the expiry of 2 years from the date of payment.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Recovery from landlord of sums paid in excess of recoverable rent, etc
content: Any person who, in any rent book or similar document, makes an entry showing or purporting to show any tenant as being in arrears in respect of any sum on account of rent which is irrecoverable by virtue of this Part of this Act shall be liable to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale, unless he proves that, at the time of the making of the entry, the landlord had a bona fide claim that the sum was recoverable.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Recovery from landlord of sums paid in excess of recoverable rent, etc
content: If, where any such entry has been made by or on behalf of any landlord, the landlord on being requested by or on behalf of the tenant to do so, refuses or neglects to cause the entry to be deleted within 7 days, the landlord shall be liable to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale, unless he proves that, at the time of the neglect or refusal to cause the entry to be deleted, he had a bona fide claim that the sum was recoverable.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Duty of landlord to supply statement of rent under previous tenancy
content: Where the rent payable under a tenancy is subject to the rent limit specified in section 88(4)(b) of this Act, the landlord shall, on being so requested in writing by the tenant, supply him with a statement in writing of the rent which was payable for the last rental period of the other tenancy referred to in that subsection.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Duty of landlord to supply statement of rent under previous tenancy
content: If, without reasonable excuse, a landlord who has received such a requestâ  (a) fails to supply the statement referred to in subsection (1) above within 21 days of receiving the request, or  (b) supplies a statement which is false in any material particular,  he shall be liable on a first conviction to a fine not exceeding Â£50 and, on a second or subsequent conviction, to a fine not exceeding Â£100.

title: Rent Act 1977
heading: Duty of landlord to supply statement of rent under previous tenancy
content: Where an offence under this section committed by a body corporate is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of, or to be attributable to any neglect on the part of, any director, manager or secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate or any person who was purporting to act in any such capacity, he as well as the body corporate shall be guilty of that offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Rents
content: A local housing authority may make such reasonable charges as they may determine for the tenancy or occupation of their houses.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Rents
content: The authority shall from time to time review rents and make such changes, either of rents generally or of particular rents, as circumstances may require.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Rents
content: In exercising their functions under this section, a local housing authority in England shall have regard in particular to any relevant standards set for them under section 193 of the Housing and Regeneration Act 2008.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Rents
content: In exercising its functions under this section, a local housing authority in Wales must:  (a) comply with any standards relating to rent or service charges which are set for it under section 111 of the Housing (Wales) Act 2014, and  (b) have regard to any guidance relating to rent or service charges which is issued under section 112 of that Act.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Increase of rent where tenancy not secure
content: This section applies where a house is let by a local housing authority on a weekly or other periodic tenancy which is not a secure tenancy or an introductory tenancy (or a dwelling (in Wales) is let by such an authority on a weekly or other periodic tenancy which is not an occupation contract).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Increase of rent where tenancy not secure
content: The rent payable under the tenancy may, without the tenancy being terminated, be increased with effect from the beginning of a rental period by a written notice of increase given by the authority to the tenant.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Increase of rent where tenancy not secure
content: The notice is not effective unlessâ  (a) it is given at least four weeks before the beginning of the rental period, or any earlier day on which the payment of rent in respect of that period falls to be made, (b) it tells the tenant of his right to terminate the tenancy and of the steps to be taken by him if he wishes to do so, and (c) it gives him the dates by which, if in accordance with subsection (4) the increase is not to be effective, a notice to quit must be received by the authority and the tenancy be made to terminate.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Increase of rent where tenancy not secure
content: Where the notice is given for the beginning of a rental period and the tenancy continues into that period, the notice shall not have effect ifâ  (a) the tenancy is terminated by notice to quit given by the tenant in accordance with the provisions (express or implied) of the tenancy, (b) the notice to quit is given before the end of the period of two weeks following the date on which the notice of increase is given, or such longer period as may be allowed by the notice of increase, and (c) the date on which the tenancy is made to terminate is not later than the earliest day on which the tenancy could be terminated by a notice to quit given by the tenant on the last day of that period.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Increase of rent where tenancy not secure
content: In this section ârental periodâ means a period in respect of which a payment of rent falls to be made.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Secure tenancies
content: A tenancy under which a dwellingâhouse in England is let as a separate dwelling is a secure tenancy at any time when the conditions described in sections 80 and 81 as the landlord condition and the tenant condition are satisfied.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Secure tenancies
content: Subsection (1) has effect subject toâ  (a) the exceptions in Schedule 1 (tenancies which are not secure tenancies), (b) sections 89(3) and (4) and 90(3) and (4) (tenancies ceasing to be secure after death of tenant), and (c) sections 91(2) and 93(2) (tenancies ceasing to be secure in consequence of assignment or subletting).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Secure tenancies
content: The provisions of this Part apply in relation to a licence to occupy a dwellingâhouse in England (whether or not granted for a consideration) as they apply in relation to a tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Secure tenancies
content: Subsection (3) does not apply to a licence granted as a temporary expedient to a person who entered the dwellingâhouse or any other land as a trespasser (whether or not, before the grant of that licence, another licence to occupy that or another dwellingâhouse had been granted to him).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: The tenant condition
content: The tenant condition is that the tenant is an individual and occupies the dwellingâhouse as his only or principal home; or, where the tenancy is a joint tenancy, that each of the joint tenants is an individual and at least one of them occupies the dwellingâhouse as his only or principal home.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Grant of secure tenancies in cases of domestic abuse
content: This section applies where a local housing authority grants a secure tenancy of a dwellingâhouse in England before the day on which paragraph 4 of Schedule 7 to the Housing and Planning Act 2016 (grant of new secure tenancies in England) comes fully into force.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Grant of secure tenancies in cases of domestic abuse
content: The local housing authority must grant a secure tenancy that is not a flexible tenancy if:  (a) the tenancy is offered to a person who is or was a tenant of some other dwellingâhouse under a qualifying tenancy (whether as the sole tenant or as a joint tenant), and  (b) the authority is satisfied that:    (i) the person or a member of the personâs household is or has been a victim of domestic abuse carried out by another person, and    (ii) the new tenancy is granted for reasons connected with that abuse.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Grant of secure tenancies in cases of domestic abuse
content: The local housing authority must grant a secure tenancy that is not a flexible tenancy if:  (a) the tenancy is offered to a person who was a joint tenant of the dwellingâhouse under a qualifying tenancy, and  (b) the authority is satisfied that:    (i) the person or a member of the personâs household is or has been a victim of domestic abuse carried out by another person, and    (ii) the new tenancy is granted for reasons connected with that abuse.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Security of tenure
content: A secure tenancy which is eitherâ  (a) a weekly or other periodic tenancy, or (b) a tenancy for a term certain but subject to termination by the landlord,  cannot be brought to an end by the landlord except as mentioned in subsection (1A).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Security of tenure
content: The tenancy may be brought to an end by the landlordâ  (a) obtainingâ    (i) an order of the court for the possession of the dwellingâhouse, and    (ii) the execution of the order, (b) obtaining an order under subsection (3), or (c) obtaining a demotion order under section 82A.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Security of tenure
content: In the case mentioned in subsection (1A)(a), the tenancy ends when the order is executed.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Security of tenure
content: Where a secure tenancy is a tenancy for a term certain but with a provision for reâentry or forfeiture, the court shall not order possession of the dwellingâhouse in pursuance of that provision, but in a case where the court would have made such an order it shall instead make an order terminating the tenancy on a date specified in the order and section 86 (periodic tenancy arising on termination of fixed term) shall apply.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Security of tenure
content: Section 146 of the Law of Property Act 1925 (restriction on and relief against forfeiture), except subsection (4) (vesting in underâlessee), and any other enactment or rule of law relating to forfeiture, shall apply in relation to proceedings for an order under subsection (3) of this section as if they were proceedings to enforce a right of reâentry or forfeiture.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Demotion because of anti-social behaviour
content: This section applies to a secure tenancy if the landlord isâ  (a) a local housing authority; (b) a housing action trust; (c) a private registered provider of social housing; (d) a registered social landlord.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Demotion because of anti-social behaviour
content: A demotion order has the following effectâ  (a) the secure tenancy is terminated with effect from the date specified in the order; (b) if the tenant remains in occupation of the dwellingâhouse after that date a demoted tenancy is created with effect from that date; (c) it is a term of the demoted tenancy that any arrears of rent payable at the termination of the secure tenancy become payable under the demoted tenancy; (d) it is also a term of the demoted tenancy that any rent paid in advance or overpaid at the termination of the secure tenancy is credited to the tenantâs liability to pay rent under the demoted tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Demotion because of anti-social behaviour
content: The court must not make a demotion order unless it is satisfiedâ  (a) that the tenant or a person residing in or visiting the dwellingâhouse has engaged or has threatened to engage inâ    (i) conduct that is capable of causing nuisance or annoyance to some person (who need not be a particular identified person) and that directly or indirectly relates to or affects the landlordâs housing management functions, or    (ii) conduct that consists of or involves using housing accommodation owned or managed by the landlord for an unlawful purpose, and (b) that it is reasonable to make the order.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Demotion because of anti-social behaviour
content: Each of the following has effect in respect of a demoted tenancy at the time it is created by virtue of an order under this section as it has effect in relation to the secure tenancy at the time it is terminated by virtue of the orderâ  (a) the parties to the tenancy; (b) the period of the tenancy; (c) the amount of the rent; (d) the dates on which the rent is payable.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Demotion because of anti-social behaviour
content: Subsection (5)(b) does not apply if the secure tenancy was for a fixed term and in such a case the demoted tenancy is a weekly periodic tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Demotion because of anti-social behaviour
content: If the landlord of the demoted tenancy serves on the tenant a statement of any other express terms of the secure tenancy which are to apply to the demoted tenancy such terms are also terms of the demoted tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Demotion because of anti-social behaviour
content: For the purposes of this section a demoted tenancy isâ  (a) a tenancy to which section 143A of the Housing Act 1996 applies if the landlord of the secure tenancy is a local housing authority or a housing action trust; (b) a tenancy to which section 20B of the Housing Act 1988 applies if the landlord of the secure tenancy is a private registered provider of social housing or a registered social landlord.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Proceedings for possession or termination: general notice requirements
content: The court shall not entertain proceedings to which this section applies unlessâ  (a) the landlord has served a notice on the tenant complying with the provisions of this section, or (b) the court considers it just and equitable to dispense with the requirement of such a notice.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Proceedings for possession or termination: general notice requirements
content: This section applies in relation to proceedings for an order mentioned in section 82(1A) other thanâ  (a) proceedings for possession of a dwellingâhouse under section 84A (absolute ground for possession for antiâsocial behaviour), including proceedings where possession is also sought on one or more of the grounds set out in Schedule 2, or (b) proceedings for possession of a dwellingâhouse under section 107D (recovery of possession on expiry of flexible tenancy).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Proceedings for possession or termination: general notice requirements
content: A notice under this section shallâ  (a) be in a form prescribed by regulations made by the Secretary of State, (b) specify the ground on which the court will be asked to make the order, and (c) give particulars of that ground.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Proceedings for possession or termination: general notice requirements
content: Where the tenancy is a periodic tenancy and the ground or one of the grounds specified in the notice is Ground 2 in Schedule 2 (nuisance or other antiâsocial behaviour), the noticeâ  (a)(i) shall also state that proceedings for the possession of the dwellingâhouse may be begun immediately, and (ii) specify the date sought by the landlord as the date on which the tenant is to give up possession of the dwellingâhouse, and (b) shall contain such other matters as may be prescribed by regulations.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Proceedings for possession or termination: general notice requirements
content: Where the tenancy is a periodic tenancy and Ground 2 in Schedule 2 is not specified in the notice, the noticeâ  (a) shall also specify the date after which proceedings for the possession of the dwellingâhouse may be begun, and (b) ceases to be in force twelve months after the date so specified.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Proceedings for possession or termination: general notice requirements
content: If the proceedings are for a demotion order under section 82A the noticeâ  (a) must specify the date after which the proceedings may be begun; and (b) ceases to be in force twelve months after the date so specified.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Proceedings for possession or termination: general notice requirements
content: The date specified in accordance with subsection (3) or (4) or (4A) must not be earlier than the date on which the tenancy could, apart from this Part, be brought to an end by notice to quit given by the landlord on the same date as the notice under this section.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Proceedings for possession or termination: general notice requirements
content: Where a notice under this section is served with respect to a secure tenancy for a term certain, it has effect also with respect to any periodic tenancy arising on the termination of that tenancy by virtue of section 86; and subsections (3) to (5) do not apply to the notice.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Proceedings for possession or termination: general notice requirements
content: Regulations under this section shall be made by statutory instrument and may make different provision with respect to different cases or descriptions of case, including different provision for different areas.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Grounds and orders for possession
content: The court shall not make an order for the possession of a dwellingâhouse let under a secure tenancy except on one or more of the grounds set out in Schedule 2 or in accordance with section 84A (absolute ground for possession for antiâsocial behaviour) or section 107D (recovery of possession on expiry of flexible tenancy).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Grounds and orders for possession
content: The court shall not make an order for possessionâ  (a) on the grounds set out in Part I of Schedule 2 (grounds 1 to 8), unless it considers it reasonable to make the order, (b) on the grounds set out in Part II of that Schedule (grounds 9 to 11), unless it is satisfied that suitable accommodation will be available for the tenant when the order takes effect, (c) on the grounds set out in Part III of that Schedule (grounds 12 to 16), unless it both considers it reasonable to make the order and is satisfied that suitable accommodation will be available for the tenant when the order takes effect;  and Part IV of that Schedule has effect for determining whether suitable accommodation will be available for a tenant.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Grounds and orders for possession
content: Where a notice under section 83 or 83ZA has been served on the tenant, the court shall not make an order on any of the grounds mentioned in subsection (2) unless the ground is specified in the notice; but the grounds so specified may be altered or added to with the leave of the court.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Grounds and orders for possession
content: Where a date is specified in a notice under section 83 in accordance with subsection (3) of that section, the court shall not make an order which requires the tenant to give up possession of the dwellingâhouse in question before the date so specified.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Extended discretion of court in certain proceedings for possession
content: Where proceedings are brought for possession of a dwellingâhouse let under a secure tenancy on any of the grounds set out in Part I or Part III of Schedule 2 (grounds 1 to 8 and 12 to 16: cases in which the court must be satisfied that it is reasonable to make a possession order), the court may adjourn the proceedings for such period or periods as it thinks fit.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Extended discretion of court in certain proceedings for possession
content: On the making of an order for possession of such a dwellingâhouse on any of those grounds, or at any time before the execution of the order, the court mayâ (a) stay or suspend the execution of the order, or (b) postpone the date of possession, for such period or periods as the court thinks fit.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Extended discretion of court in certain proceedings for possession
content: On such an adjournment, stay, suspension or postponement the courtâ (a) shall impose conditions with respect to the payment by the tenant of arrears of rent (if any) and rent unless it considers that to do so would cause exceptional hardship to the tenant or would otherwise be unreasonable, and (b) may impose such other conditions as it thinks fit.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Extended discretion of court in certain proceedings for possession
content: The court may discharge or rescind the order for possession if it thinks it appropriate to do so having had regard toâ (a) any conditions imposed under subsection (3), and (b) the conduct of the tenant in connection with those conditions.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Proceedings for possession on nonâabsolute grounds: antiâsocial behaviour
content: This section applies if the court is considering under section 84(2)(a) whether it is reasonable to make an order for possession on ground 2 set out in Part I of Schedule 2 (conduct of tenant or other person).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Periodic tenancy arising on termination of fixed term
content: Where a secure tenancy (âthe first tenancyâ) is a tenancy for a term certain and comes to an endâ  (a) by effluxion of time, or (b) by an order of the court under section 82(3) (termination in pursuance of provision for reâentry or forfeiture),  a periodic tenancy of the same dwellingâhouse arises by virtue of this section, unless the tenant is granted another secure tenancy of the same dwellingâhouse (whether a tenancy for a term certain or a periodic tenancy) to begin on the coming to an end of the first tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Periodic tenancy arising on termination of fixed term
content: Where a periodic tenancy arises by virtue of this sectionâ  (a) the periods of the tenancy are the same as those for which rent was last payable under the first tenancy, and (b) the parties and the terms of the tenancy are the same as those of the first tenancy at the end of it;  except that the terms are confined to those which are compatible with a periodic tenancy and do not include any provision for reâentry or forfeiture.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Persons qualified to succeed tenant: England
content: A person (âPâ) is qualified to succeed the tenant under a secure tenancy of a dwellingâhouse in England ifâ (a) P occupies the dwellingâhouse as P's only or principal home at the time of the tenant's death, and (b) P is the tenant's spouse or civil partner.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Persons qualified to succeed tenant: England
content: A person (âPâ) is qualified to succeed the tenant under a secure tenancy of a dwellingâhouse in England ifâ (a) at the time of the tenant's death the dwellingâhouse is not occupied by a spouse or civil partner of the tenant as his or her only or principal home, and (b) an express term of the tenancy makes provision for a person other than such a spouse or civil partner of the tenant to succeed to the tenancy, and (c) P's succession is in accordance with that term.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Persons qualified to succeed tenant: England
content: Subsection (1) or (2) does not apply if the tenant was a successor as defined in section 88.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Persons qualified to succeed tenant: England
content: In such a case, a person (âPâ) is qualified to succeed the tenant ifâ (a) an express term of the tenancy makes provision for a person to succeed a successor to the tenancy, and (b) P's succession is in accordance with that term.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Persons qualified to succeed tenant: England
content: For the purposes of this section, a person who was living with the tenant as if they were a married couple or civil partners is to be treated as the tenantâs spouse or civil partner.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Persons qualified to succeed tenant: England
content: Subsection (5) applies if, on the death of the tenant, there is by virtue of subsection (5) more than one person who fulfils the condition in subsection (1)(b).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Persons qualified to succeed tenant: England
content: Such one of those persons as may be agreed between them or as may, where there is no such agreement, be selected by the landlord is for the purpose of this section to be treated as the tenantâs spouse or civil partner.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Cases where the tenant is a successor
content: The tenant is himself a successor ifâ (a) the tenancy vested in him by virtue of section 89 (succession to a periodic tenancy), or (b) he was a joint tenant and has become the sole tenant, or (c) the tenancy arose by virtue of section 86 (periodic tenancy arising on ending of term certain) and the first tenancy there mentioned was granted to another person or jointly to him and another person, or (d) he became the tenant on the tenancy being assigned to him, or (e) he became the tenant on the tenancy being vested in him on the death of the previous tenant.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Cases where the tenant is a successor
content: A tenant to whom the tenancy was assigned in pursuance of an order under section 24 of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 or section 17(1) of the Matrimonial and Family Proceedings Act 1984 is a successor only if the other party to the marriage was a successor.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Cases where the tenant is a successor
content: A tenant to whom the tenancy was assigned by virtue of section 92 (assignments by way of exchange) is a successor only if he was a successor in relation to the tenancy which he himself assigned by virtue of that section.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Cases where the tenant is a successor
content: Where within six months of the coming to an end of a secure tenancy which is a periodic tenancy (âthe former tenancyâ) the tenant becomes a tenant under another secure tenancy which is a periodic tenancy, andâ (a) the tenant was a successor in relation to the former tenancy, and (b) under the other tenancy either the dwellingâhouse or the landlord, or both, are the same as under the former tenancy, the tenant is also a successor in relation to the other tenancy unless the agreement creating that tenancy otherwise provides.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Succession to periodic tenancy
content: This section applies where a secure tenant dies and the tenancy is a periodic tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Succession to periodic tenancy
content: Where there is a person qualified to succeed the tenant under section 86A, the tenancy vests by virtue of this sectionâ (a) in that person, or (b) if there is more than one such person, in such one of them as may be agreed between them or as may, where there is no agreement, be selected by the landlord.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Succession to periodic tenancy
content: Where there is a person qualified to succeed the tenant under section 87, the tenancy vests by virtue of this section in that person, or if there is more than one such person in the one to be preferred in accordance with the following rulesâ (a) the tenantâs spouse or civil partner is to be preferred to another member of the tenantâs family; (b) of two or more other members of the tenantâs family such of them is to be preferred as may be agreed between them or as may, where there is no such agreement, be selected by the landlord.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Succession to periodic tenancy
content: Where there is no person qualified to succeed the tenant, the tenancy ceases to be a secure tenancyâ (a) when it is vested or otherwise disposed of in the course of the administration of the tenantâs estate, unless the vesting or other disposal is in pursuance of an order made under specified property adjustment provisions, or (b) when it is known that when the tenancy is so vested or disposed of it will not be in pursuance of such an order.  A tenancy which ceases to be a secure tenancy by virtue of this section cannot subsequently become a secure tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Devolution of term certain
content: This section applies where a secure tenant dies and the tenancy is a tenancy for a term certain.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Devolution of term certain
content: The tenancy remains a secure tenancy untilâ (a) it is vested or otherwise disposed of in the course of the administration of the tenantâs estate, or (b) it is known that when it is so vested or disposed of it will not be a secure tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Devolution of term certain
content: The tenancy ceases to be a secure tenancy on being vested or otherwise disposed of in the course of administration of the tenantâs estate, unlessâ (a) the vesting or other disposal is in pursuance of an order made under specified property adjustment provisions, or (b) the vesting or other disposal is to a person qualified to succeed the tenant.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Devolution of term certain
content: A tenancy which ceases to be a secure tenancy by virtue of this section cannot subsequently become a secure tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Devolution of term certain
content: The following provisions apply where a tenancy that was a secure tenancy of a dwellingâhouse in England (a) has been vested or otherwise disposed of in the course of the administration of the secure tenantâs estate, and (b) has ceased to be a secure tenancy by virtue of this section.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignment in general prohibited
content: A secure tenancy which isâ (a) a periodic tenancy, or (b) a tenancy for a term certain granted on or after 5th November 1982,  is not capable of being assigned except in the cases mentioned in subsection (3).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignment in general prohibited
content: If a secure tenancy for a term certain granted before 5th November 1982 is assigned, then, except in the cases mentioned in subsection (3), it ceases to be a secure tenancy and cannot subsequently become a secure tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignment in general prohibited
content: The exceptions areâ (a) an assignment in accordance with section 92 (assignment by way of exchange); (b) an assignment in pursuance of an order made under specified property adjustment provisions, or (c) an assignment to a person who would be qualified to succeed the tenant if the tenant died immediately before the assignment.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignments by way of exchange
content: It is a term of every secure tenancy that the tenancy may, with the written consent of the landlord, assign the tenancy toâ (a) another secure tenant who satisfies the condition in subsection (2), (b) an assured tenant who satisfies the conditions in subsection (2A), or (c) a tenant who is a secure contractâholder and who satisfies the conditions in subsection (2B).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignments by way of exchange
content: The condition is that the other secure tenant has the written consent of his landlord to an assignment of his tenancy either to the firstâmentioned tenant or to another secure tenant who satisfies the condition in this subsection.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignments by way of exchange
content: The conditions to be satisfied with respect to an assured tenant areâ (a) that the landlord under his assured tenancy is the Regulator of Social Housing, a private registered provider of social housing, a registered social landlord or a housing trust which is a charity; and (b) that he intends to assign his assured tenancy to the secure tenant referred to in subsection (1) or to another secure tenant who satisfies the condition in subsection (2).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignments by way of exchange
content: The conditions to be satisfied with respect to a tenant who is a secure contractâholder are thatâ (a) their landlord is a community landlord, and (b) they intend to transfer their secure contract toâ    (i) the secure tenant referred to in subsection (1),    (ii) another secure tenant who satisfies the condition in subsection (2), or    (iii) another secure contractâholder.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignments by way of exchange
content: The consent required by virtue of this section shall not be withheld except on one or more of the grounds set out in Schedule 3, and if withheld otherwise than on one of those grounds shall be treated as given.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignments by way of exchange
content: The landlord may not rely on any of the grounds set out in Schedule 3 unless he has, within 42 days of the tenantâs application for the consent, served on the tenant a notice specifying the ground and giving particulars of it.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignments by way of exchange
content: Where rent lawfully due from the tenant has not been paid or an obligation of the tenancy has been broken or not performed, the consent required by virtue of this section may be given subject to a condition requiring the tenant to pay the outstanding rent, remedy the breach or perform the obligation.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignments by way of exchange
content: Except as provided by subsection (5), a consent required by virtue of this section cannot be given subject to a condition, and a condition imposed otherwise than as so provided shall be disregarded.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Assignments by way of exchange
content: In this section, the following terms have the same meaning as in the Renting Homes (Wales) Act 2016 (anaw 1)â (a) âcommunity landlordâ (see section 9 of that Act); (b) âcontractâholderâ (see section 7 (see also section 48) of that Act); (c) âsecure contractâ (see section 8 of that Act).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Lodgers and subletting
content: It is a term of every secure tenancy that the tenantâ (a) may allow any persons to reside as lodgers in the dwellingâhouse, but (b) will not, without the written consent of the landlord, sublet or part with possession of part of the dwellingâhouse.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Lodgers and subletting
content: If the tenant under a secure tenancy parts with the possession of the dwellingâhouse or sublets the whole of it (or sublets first part of it and then the remainder), the tenancy ceases to be a secure tenancy and cannot subsequently become a secure tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Consent to subletting
content: This section applies to the consent required by virtue of section 93(1)(b) (landlordâs consent to subletting of part of dwellingâhouse).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Consent to subletting
content: Consent shall not be unreasonably withheld (and if unreasonably withheld shall be treated as given), and if a question arises whether the withholding of consent was unreasonable it is for the landlord to show that it was not.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Consent to subletting
content: In determining that question the following matters, if shown by the landlord, are among those to be taken into accountâ (a) that the consent would lead to overcrowding of the dwellingâhouse within the meaning of Part X (overcrowding); (b) that the landlord proposes to carry out works on the dwellingâhouse, or on the building of which it forms part, and that the proposed works will affect the accommodation likely to be used by the subâtenant who would reside in the dwellingâhouse as a result of the consent.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Consent to subletting
content: Consent may be validly given notwithstanding that it follows, instead of preceding, the action requiring it.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Consent to subletting
content: Consent cannot be given subject to a condition (and it purporting to be given subject to a condition shall be treated as given unconditionally).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Consent to subletting
content: Where the tenant has applied in writing for consent, thenâ (a) if the landlord refuses to give consent, it shall give the tenant a written statement of the reasons why consent was refused, and (b) if the landlord neither gives nor refuses to give consent within a reasonable time, consent shall be taken to have been withheld.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: The right to buy
content: A secure tenant of a dwellingâhouse in England has the right to buy, that is to say, the right, in the circumstances and subject to the conditions and exceptions stated in the following provisions of this Partâ (a) if the dwellingâhouse is a house and the landlord owns the freehold, to acquire the freehold of the dwellingâhouse; (b) if the landlord does not own the freehold or if the dwellingâhouse is a flat (whether or not the landlord owns the freehold), to be granted a lease of the dwellingâhouse.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: The right to buy
content: Where a secure tenancy is a joint tenancy then, whether or not each of the joint tenants occupies the dwellingâhouse as his only or principal home, the right to buy belongs jointly to all of them or to such one or more of them as may be agreed between them; but such an agreement is not valid unless the person or at least one of the persons to whom the right to buy is to belong occupies the dwellingâhouse as his only or principal home.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: The right to buy
content: For the purposes of this Part, a dwellingâhouse which is a commonhold unit (within the meaning of the Commonhold and Leasehold Reform Act 2002) shall be treated as a house and not as a flat.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Qualifying period for right to buy
content: The right to buy does not arise unless the period which, in accordance with Schedule 4, is to be taken into account for the purposes of this section is at least three years.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Qualifying period for right to buy
content: Where the secure tenancy is a joint tenancy the condition in subsection (1) need be satisfied with respect to one only of the joint tenants.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Circumstances in which the right to buy cannot be exercised
content: The right to buy cannot be exercised if the tenant is subject to an order of the court for possession of the dwellingâhouse.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Circumstances in which the right to buy cannot be exercised
content: The right to buy cannot be exercised if the person, or one of the persons, to whom the right to buy belongsâ (a) has made a bankruptcy application that has not been determined or has a bankruptcy petition pending against him, (b) is an undischarged bankrupt, (c) has made a composition or arrangement with his creditors the terms of which remain to be fulfilled, or (d) is a person in relation to whom a moratorium period under a debt relief order applies (under Part 7A of the Insolvency Act 1986).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Circumstances in which the right to buy cannot be exercised
content: The right to buy cannot be exercised at any time during the suspension period under an order made under section 121A in respect of the secure tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Order suspending right to buy because of anti-social behaviour
content: The court may, on the application of the landlord under a secure tenancy, make a suspension order in respect of the tenancy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Order suspending right to buy because of anti-social behaviour
content: A suspension order is an order providing that the right to buy may not be exercised in relation to the dwelling-house during such period as is specified in the order (âthe suspension periodâ).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Order suspending right to buy because of anti-social behaviour
content: The court must not make a suspension order unless it is satisfiedâ (a) that the tenant, or a person residing in or visiting the dwelling-house, has engaged or threatened to engage inâ    (i) conduct capable of causing nuisance or annoyance and directly or indirectly related to the landlord's housing management functions, or    (ii) conduct involving using the accommodation for an unlawful purpose, and (b) that it is reasonable to make the order.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Order suspending right to buy because of anti-social behaviour
content: When deciding whether it is reasonable to make the order, the court must consider, in particularâ (a) whether it is desirable for the dwelling-house to be managed by the landlord during the suspension period; and (b) where the conduct consists of conduct capable of causing nuisance or annoyance, the effect that the conduct (or threat) has had on other persons, or would have if repeated.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Order suspending right to buy because of anti-social behaviour
content: Where a suspension order is madeâ (a) any existing claim to exercise the right to buy is ineffective from the beginning of the suspension period, (b) section 138(1) does not apply to the landlord in connection with such a claim at any time after that period begins, but (c) the order does not affect the computation of any period in accordance with Schedule 4.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Order suspending right to buy because of anti-social behaviour
content: The court may, on the application of the landlord, make (on one or more occasions) a further order which extends the suspension period by such period as is specified in the further order.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Order suspending right to buy because of anti-social behaviour
content: The court must not make such a further order unless it is satisfiedâ (a) that since the last suspension order, the tenant or a person residing or visiting has engaged or threatened to engage in the conduct described in subsection (3)(a), and (b) that it is reasonable to make the further order.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Order suspending right to buy because of anti-social behaviour
content: When deciding whether it is reasonable to make such a further order, the court must consider, in particularâ (a) whether it is desirable for the dwelling-house to be managed by the landlord during the further suspension period; and (b) where the conduct consists of conduct capable of causing nuisance or annoyance, the effect of that conduct (or threat) on others or if repeated.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Order suspending right to buy because of anti-social behaviour
content: In this section any reference to the tenant under a secure tenancy is, in relation to a joint tenancy, a reference to any of the joint tenants.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Order suspending right to buy because of anti-social behaviour
content: In this section âhousing accommodationâ includesâ (a) flats, lodging-houses and hostels; (b) any yard, garden, outhouses and appurtenances belonging to the accommodation or usually enjoyed with it; (c) any common areas used in connection with the accommodation.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Information to help tenants decide whether to exercise right to buy etc.
content: Every body which lets dwellingâhouses in England under secure tenancies shall prepare a document that contains information for its secure tenants about such matters as are specified in an order made by the Secretary of State.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Information to help tenants decide whether to exercise right to buy etc.
content: The matters that may be so specified are matters which the Secretary of State considers that it would be desirable for secure tenants to have information about when considering whether to exercise the right to buy or the right to acquire on rent to mortgage terms.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Information to help tenants decide whether to exercise right to buy etc.
content: The information contained in the document shall be restricted to information about the specified matters, and the information about those mattersâ (a) shall be such as the body concerned considers appropriate, but (b) shall be in a form which the body considers best suited to explaining those matters in simple terms.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Information to help tenants decide whether to exercise right to buy etc.
content: Once a body has prepared the document required by subsection (1), it shall revise it as often as it considers necessary in order to ensure that the information contained in itâ (a) is kept up to date so far as is reasonably practicable, and (b) reflects any changes in the matters for the time being specified in an order under this section.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Information to help tenants decide whether to exercise right to buy etc.
content: An order under this section shall be made by statutory instrument which shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Provision of information
content: This section sets out when the document prepared by a body under section 121AA is to be published or otherwise made available.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Provision of information
content: The body shallâ (a) publish the document (whether in its original or a revised form), and (b) supply copies of it to the bodyâs secure tenants of dwellingâhouses in England,  at such times as may be prescribed by, and otherwise in accordance with, an order made by the Secretary of State.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Provision of information
content: The body shall make copies of the current version of the document available to be supplied, free of charge, to persons requesting them.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Provision of information
content: The copies must be made available for that purposeâ (a) at the bodyâs principal offices, and (b) at such other places as it considers appropriate,  at reasonable hours.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Provision of information
content: The body shall take such steps as it considers appropriate to bring to the attention of its secure tenants of dwellingâhouses in England the fact that copies of the current version of the document can be obtained free of charge from the places where, and at the times when, they are made available in accordance with subsection (4).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Provision of information
content: In this section any reference to the current version of the document is to the version of the document that was last published by the body in accordance with subsection (2)(a).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Tenantâs notice claiming to exercise right to buy
content: A secure tenant claims to exercise the right to buy by written notice to that effect served on the landlord.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Tenantâs notice claiming to exercise right to buy
content: In this Part âthe relevant timeâ, in relation to an exercise of the right to buy, means the date on which that notice is served.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Tenantâs notice claiming to exercise right to buy
content: The notice may be withdrawn at any time by notice in writing served on the landlord.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Claim to share right to buy with members of family
content: A secure tenant may in his notice under section 122 require that not more than three members of his family who are not joint tenants but occupy the dwellingâhouse as their only or principal home should share the right to buy with him.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Claim to share right to buy with members of family
content: He may validly do so in the case of any such member only ifâ (a) that member is his spouse, is his civil partner or has been residing with him throughout the period of twelve months ending with the giving of the notice, or (b) the landlord consents.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Claim to share right to buy with members of family
content: Where by such a notice any members of the tenantâs family are validly required to share the right to buy with the tenant, the right to buy belongs to the tenant and those members jointly and he and they shall be treated for the purposes of this Part as joint tenants.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice admitting or denying right to buy
content: Where a notice under section 122 has been served by the tenant, the landlord shall, unless the notice is withdrawn, serve on the tenant within the period specified in subsection (2) a written notice eitherâ (a) admitting his right, or (b) denying it and stating the reasons why, in the opinion of the landlord, the tenant does not have the right to buy.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice admitting or denying right to buy
content: The period for serving a notice under this section is four weeks where the requirement of section 119 is satisfied by a period or periods during which the landlord was the landlord on which the tenantâs notice under section 122 was served, and eight weeks in any other case.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice of purchase price and other matters
content: Where a secure tenant has claimed to exercise the right to buy and that right has been established (whether by the landlordâs admission or otherwise), the landlord shallâ (a) within eight weeks where the right is that mentioned in section 118(1)(a) (right to acquire freehold), and (b) within twelve weeks where the right is that mentioned in section 118(1)(b) (right to acquire leasehold interest), serve on the tenant a notice complying with this section.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice of purchase price and other matters
content: The notice shall describe the dwellingâhouse, shall state the price at which, in the opinion of the landlord, the tenant is entitled to have the freehold conveyed or, as the case may be, the lease granted to him and shall, for the purpose of showing how the price has been arrived at, stateâ (a) the value at the relevant time, (b) the improvements disregarded in pursuance of section 127 (improvements to be disregarded in determining value), and (c) the discount to which the tenant is entitled, stating the period to be taken into account under section 129 (discount) and, where applicable, the amount mentioned in section 130(1) (reduction for previous discount) or section 131(1) or (2) (limits on amount of discount).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice of purchase price and other matters
content: The notice shall state the provisions which, in the opinion of the landlord, should be contained in the conveyance or grant.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice of purchase price and other matters
content: Where the notice states provisions which would enable the landlord to recover from the tenantâ (a) service charges, or (b) improvement contributions, the notice shall also contain the estimates and other information required by section 125A (service charges) or 125B (improvement contributions).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice of purchase price and other matters
content: The notice shall also inform the tenant ofâ (a) the effect of sections 125D and 125E(1) and (4) (tenantâs notice of intention, landlordâs notice in default and effect of failure to comply), (b) his right under section 128 to have the value of the dwellingâhouse at the relevant time determined or reâdetermined by the district valuer, (c) the effect of section 136(2) (change of tenant after service of notice under section 125), (d) the effect of sections 140 and 141(1), (2) and (4) (landlordâs notices to complete and effect of failure to comply), (e) the effect of the provisions of this Part relating to the right to acquire on rent to mortgage terms, and (f) the relevant amount and multipliers for the time being declared by the Secretary of State for the purposes of section 143B.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Estimates and information about service charges
content: A landlordâs notice under section 125 shall state as regards service charges (excluding, in the case of a flat, charges to which subsection (2) applies)â (a) the landlordâs estimate of the average annual amount (at current prices) which would be payable in respect of each head of charge in the reference period, and (b) the aggregate of those estimated amounts, and shall contain a statement of the reference period adopted for the purpose of the estimates.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Estimates and information about service charges
content: A landlordâs notice under section 125 given in respect of a flat shall, as regards service charges in respect of repairs (including works for the making good of structural defects), containâ (a) the estimates required by subsection (3), together with a statement of the reference period adopted for the purpose of the estimates, and (b) a statement of the effect ofâ     paragraph 16B of Schedule 6 (which restricts by reference to the estimates the amounts payable by the tenant), and     section 450A and the regulations made under that section (right to a loan in respect of certain service charges).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Estimates and information about service charges
content: The following estimates are required for works in respect of which the landlord considers that costs may be incurred in the reference periodâ (a) for works itemised in the notice, estimates of the amount (at current prices) of the likely cost of, and of the tenantâs likely contribution in respect of, each item, and the aggregate amounts of those estimated costs and contributions, and (b) for works not so itemised, an estimate of the average annual amount (at current prices) which the landlord considers is likely to be payable by the tenant.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Estimates and information about improvement contributions
content: A landlordâs notice under section 125 given in respect of a flat shall, as regards improvement contributions, containâ (a) the estimates required by this section, together with a statement of the reference period adopted for the purpose of the estimates, and (b) a statement of the effect of paragraph 16C of Schedule 6 (which restricts by reference to the estimates the amounts payable by the tenant).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Estimates and information about improvement contributions
content: Estimates are required for works in respect of which the landlord considers that costs may be incurred in the reference period.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Estimates and information about improvement contributions
content: The works to which the estimates relate shall be itemised and the estimates shall showâ (a) the amount (at current prices) of the likely cost of, and of the tenantâs likely contribution in respect of, each item, and (b) the aggregate amounts of those estimated costs and contributions.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Reference period for purposes of ss.125A and 125B
content: The reference period for the purposes of the estimates required by section 125A or 125B is the periodâ (a) beginning on such date not more than six months after the notice is given as the landlord may reasonably specify as being a date by which the conveyance will have been made or the lease granted, and (b) ending five years after that date or, where the notice states that the conveyance or lease will provide for a service charge or improvement contribution to be calculated by reference to a specified annual period, with the end of the fifth such period beginning after that date.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Reference period for purposes of ss.125A and 125B
content: For the purpose of the estimates it shall be assumed that the conveyance will be made or the lease granted at the beginning of the reference period on the terms stated in the notice.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Tenantâs notice of intention
content: Where a notice under section 125 has been served on a secure tenant, he shall within the period specified in subsection (2) eitherâ (a) serve a written notice on the landlord stating either that he intends to pursue his claim to exercise the right to buy or that he withdraws that claim, or (b) serve a notice under section 144 claiming to exercise the right to acquire on rent to mortgage terms.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Tenantâs notice of intention
content: The period for serving a notice under subsection (1) is the period of twelve weeks beginning with whichever of the following is the laterâ (a) the service of the notice under section 125, or (b) where the tenant exercises his right to have the value of the dwellingâhouse determined or reâdetermined by the district valuer (or where the landlord exercises his right to have the value of the dwellingâhouse reâdetermined by the district valuer), the relevant event.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Tenantâs notice of intention
content: In subsection (2)(b) âthe relevant eventâ meansâ (a) where a review notice was capable of being served under section 128A in relation to the determination or reâdetermination but no such notice was served during the period permitted by that section, the service of the notice under section 128(5) stating the effect of the determination or reâdetermination, (b) where a review notice was served under section 128A in relation to the determination or reâdetermination and section 128B(3) applied, the service on the tenant of the notice under section 128B(3), (c) where a review notice was served under section 128A in relation to the determination or reâdetermination and section 128B(5) applied, the service of the notice under section 128B(7).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice in default
content: The landlord may, at any time after the end of the period specified in section 125D(2) or, as the case may require, section 136(2), serve on the tenant a written noticeâ (a) requiring him, if he has failed to serve the notice required by section 125D(1), to serve that notice within 28 days, and (b) informing him of the effect of this subsection and subsection (4).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice in default
content: At any time before the end of the period mentioned in subsection (1)(a) (or that period as previously extended) the landlord may by written notice served on the tenant extend it (or further extend it).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice in default
content: If at any time before the end of that period (or that period as extended under subsection (2)) the circumstances are such that it would not be reasonable to expect the tenant to comply with a notice under this section, that period (or that period as so extended) shall by virtue of this subsection be extended (or further extended) until 28 days after the time when those circumstances no longer obtain.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Landlordâs notice in default
content: If the tenant does not comply with a notice under this section, the notice claiming to exercise the right to buy shall be deemed to be withdrawn at the end of that period (or, as the case may require, that period as extended under subsection (2) or (3)).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Purchase price
content: The price payable for a dwellingâhouse on a conveyance or grant in pursuance of this Part isâ (a) the amount which under section 127 is to be taken as its value at the relevant time, less (b) the discount to which the purchaser is entitled under this Part.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Purchase price
content: References in this Part to the purchase price include references to the consideration for the grant of a lease.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Discount
content: Subject to the following provisions of this Part, a person exercising the right to buy is entitled to a discount of a percentage calculated by reference to the period which is to be taken into account in accordance with Schedule 4 (qualifying period for right to buy and discount).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Discount
content: The discount is, subject to any order under subsection (2A)â (a) in the case of a house, 35 per cent plus one per cent for each complete year by which the qualifying period exceeds five years, up to a maximum of 60 per cent; (b) in the case of a flat, 50 per cent plus two per cent for each complete year by which the qualifying period exceeds five years, up to a maximum of 70 per cent.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Discount
content: Where joint tenants exercise the right to buy, Schedule 4 shall be construed as if for the secure tenant there were substituted that one of the joint tenants whose substitution will produce the largest discount.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Reduction of discount where previous discount given
content: There shall be deducted from the discount an amount equal to any previous discount qualifying, or the aggregate of previous discounts qualifying, under the provisions of this section.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Reduction of discount where previous discount given
content: A âprevious discountâ means a discount given before the relevant timeâ (a) on conveyance of the freehold, or a grant or assignment of a long lease, of a dwellingâhouse by a person within paragraph 7 or 7A of Schedule 4 (public sector landlords) or in such circumstances as may be prescribed by order of the Secretary of State, or â¦ (b) in pursuance of the provision required by paragraph 1 of Schedule 8 (terms of shared ownership leaseâ¦), or any other provision to the like effect, or (c) in pursuance of any provision of, or required by this Part by virtue of section 17 of the Housing Act 1996 (the right to acquire).

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Reduction of discount where previous discount given
content: A previous discount qualifies for the purposes of this section if it was givenâ (a) to the person or one of the persons exercising the right to buy, or (b) to the spouse or civil partner of that person or one of those persons (if they are living together at the relevant time), or (c) to a deceased spouse or deceased civil partner of that person or one of those persons (if they were living together at the time of the death); and where a previous discount was given to two or more persons jointly, this section has effect as if each of them had been given an equal proportion of the discount.

title: Housing Act 1985
heading: Reduction of discount where previous discount given
